pre_battle_speeches.text: My respects are due to the Ashikaga commander! I thank him for his efforts in marching to our aid! Let us demonstrate that we are worth helping!
By the Seven Lucky Gods, I am pleased to see our allies, the Ashikaga! They are ancient in honour, and noble fighters!
How can we fail when we are aided by the Ashikaga, the clan of the Shoguns themselves? I thank them for it!
I thank our allies, the noble and ancient Ashikaga clan, for sending troops to our aid! Their presence is a living fortress among us!
It is an honour to have so many Ashikaga troops at our side! They are welcome! I salute their commander, and the wise lord that sent them!
I am deeply honoured by the presence of so many Ashikaga soldiers! They have handsomely met, no, exceeded any reasonable expectation of support! I salute them!
I thank our noble allies, the Ashikaga, for their support! I had hoped for greater numbers, but their honour alone is a source of great strength.
I had hoped to see more soldiers in the field beneath Ashikaga banners, but each and every one of them is welcome today!
I salute our Ashikaga allies! I had hoped to salute a good many more of them, but these few are doubly welcome because of their rarity today!
I have some reports to hand of an Ashikaga army marching to our aid! Bishamon guide their steps, so that they arrive in time!
I have hopes that an Ashikaga army are coming to our aid! Perhaps the fighting will be over before they have the chance to take a few heads!
There is a chance, my aides tell me, that we may have Ashikaga allies in the field. This is excellent, for they are a most honourable clan!
We should honour the Chosokabe clan, who stand alongside us in this fight. We must be worthy of their friendship and sacrifice.
I am pleased that the Chosokabe have come. Friends in battle are a blessing of Bishamon!
The Chosokabe warriors who stand beside you are most welcome. They have come because they truly value our alliance.
I give my personal thanks to the noble Chosokabe, who stand alongside us today. Their mighty strength is most welcome!
I am gratified to see so many Chosokabe warriors here. Their aid is most welcome, and does them much honour.
It is good to see so many Chosokabe soldiers here. They have more than met their obligations as allies!
I thank the Chosokabe for standing with us in this fight. Their numbers may be few, but their honour is great!
I know what the Chosokabe lack in numbers, they make up in greatness. I am proud they stand with us.
I thank the noble Chosokabe for their support. I shall enjoy asking all of them to a celebration after the battle.
Even now, our noble Chosokabe allies are coming! I pray that the spirits aid them, and that they arrive in time.
As swift as an arrow in a cloudless sky, the Chosokabe are coming. Let us hope that their aim is true and timely!
I pray that the Chosokabe have marching skills to match their bowmanship! Spirits, let them arrive in time!
We should salute our fearsome Date allies. Their reputation as tough and capable warriors makes them a mighty addition to our cause.
I am heartened to see the banners of the Date on the field. Their strength, added to ours, is formidable!
The Date have raised their banners alongside ours. This must surely give the enemy cause for despair!
I salute our allies from the Date clan. Their great numbers and fearsome reputation are welcome indeed.
It is wonderful to see so many Date banners flying overhead. Their strength is a great aid to our noble cause.
The Date have sent many men to support our efforts. I hope they will have some sword-work when we are done with the foe!
We are supported by our Date allies! Their numbers may be few, but their fierce nature is a most welcome worry for the foe!
It is most welcome to see Date banners among ours. Would that there were more, but we can fight our own battles!
I thank the Date for coming to our aid. Their fierce nature will surely cancel out their lack of numbers!
Word has come that our Date allies are near and may yet arrive. Let us hope that their skill in marching matches their fierceness!
I have word that the Date are coming to our aid. I trust that their fierce nature will not be blunted by hard marching.
I hear that a Date army is nearby. Good! I will take the aid of fierce men if they come in time!
I thank the Hattori, our allies, for their aid in this battle. I am sure they will make a cunning contribution to our victory.
Our Hattori friends are most welcome today! Their cunning and skill in battle will serve our cause well!
I am honoured and thankful to our Hattori allies for their presence. They are skilled and cunning warriors, and will put fear into enemy hearts.
Our Hattori allies have done us great honour by coming to the battle in such numbers. Their strength is a most welcome addition to our own.
I am pleased that the Hattori have come to our aid in such strength. Their cunning and trickery in war will serve our cause well!
We are greatly honoured to see so many brave Hattori warriors standing with us. Their strength and worth will give the enemy pause.
I thank the noble Hattori clan for their presence! I had hoped for more men, but their worth is not measured by mere numbers!
The Hattori honour us with their presence. Their numbers belie their cunning and skill as warriors, as we will surely see today.
One Hattori warrior, it is said, has all the cunning of a fox! It is good, then, that even a few Hattori stand with us.
There is every chance that the Hattori clan will come! Their reputation for trickery will serve us well, should they arrive in time!
I have reports that the Hattori approach! They are cunning warriors, and even the rumour of their coming will dishearten our foes!
Even now, the Hattori are coming! I hope the spirits will guide their steps but, if not, we are honoured by their attempt to help.
Our worthy Hojo allies have sent an army to aid our efforts. We should be grateful to see so many noble fighters.
I thank the worthy Hojo for their aid. The sight of their banners should put fear into the enemy!
I welcome the Hojo to this fight! They are good, solid fighters, and will be of great use.
We are supported by the Hojo clan. Their numbers are as great as their strength! They are an impregnable fortress, not an army!
I had not expected so many Hojo warriors, but they are welcome allies nonetheless. Shall we show them how we fight?
I see that the Hojo clan is a true ally: so many fighters, and all to aid us! Welcome, brother warriors!
The great Hojo clan have sent us help. Their numbers are few, it is true, but they are as strong as a fortress in spirit!
Those noble Hojo warriors beside you are most welcome. If their numbers are few, their courage is magnificent!
Briefly, I must thank the Hojo for coming to our aid. I would have thanked them more, if only there had been more of them!
I have word that a Hojo army is marching to our aid. We can hope for their help, but not rely on it.
An allied Hojo army is marching towards us. Would that they would come soon! I trust they will not go astray!
Let us hope that the Hojo army can reach us in time. They are good men, but are they practiced in hard marching?
We are aided by our allies in the Mori clan. We must be make full use of their cunning in battle!
I am grateful that the Mori have sent warriors to help us. Welcome, friends! Use your cunning well today!
We are blessed with allies, and I thank the Mori for their support. I relish the chance to witness their cunning in battle!
Give thanks to the Mori for the strong army they have sent to our aid. Their cunning in battle is a great asset!
It is good to see so many fine Mori warriors here. Their strength and cunning will be of great help to us!
The sight of so many Mori banners will cause our enemies to worry. What plans are we making? What schemes? Let them doubt everything!
I give thanks to the Mori for their support. Although few in number, they are great in spirit, and cunning warriors.
I am glad in my heart to see Mori banners alongside ours. Their deceptive skills will put doubt in enemy hearts!
Our foes now ask: where are the rest of the Mori? They will see schemes and tricks where there are none, and be weakened!
I have reports that a Mori army is marching even as I speak. I pray that they can arrive before the fight is over!
I hear that a Mori army is close by. Let us hope their natural cunning does not lead them astray, and they arrive in time!
We can hope for some aid in this fight. A Mori army is nearby, and may arrive in time. Speed would serve better than cunning!
The Oda clan do us much honour by standing in the field as our allies. We must show them how well we can fight!
It is good to have the Oda as allies. They are strong and worthy friends. Let us be equally worthy.
I thank the Oda for their efforts today! Their warriors are welcome beside our ranks! I trust they are full of fight!
The Oda clan have honoured us by sending a mighty force to our aid. I thank them for their efforts!
It is good to see so many Oda banners flying on the breeze. I had only hoped for such commitment to our cause!
It is a blessing to see that the Oda have come to our aid in such numbers. Their skill in arms is a further blessing!
The Oda clan deserve our thanks for supporting us in this fight. Their numbers are small, but their worth is great.
It is good to see even one Oda banner next to ours! Their strength is legendary, regardless of their actual numbers!
I thank the Oda clan for their help today! All men who bear arms and defy the enemy are welcome to fight at my side!
Even now, I have reports that an army of fierce Oda warriors marches to our aid. I hope we will leave some foes for them!
I hear an Oda army is coming. Let us hope that they arrive in time, and that they still have strength left for a fight!
Even now, an Oda army is marching to our aid! I have high hopes that they will arrive in time to influence this fight!
We must thank the respected Shimazu for their aid. We are honoured by their support.
It is good that we have the Shimazu with us. They are a worthy clan, and clever fighters.
I give my thanks to the Shimazu commander, our ally today! His men are a most welcome addition to our strength!
The respected Shimazu are here in great strength. Their commitment to this battle does us great honour.
It is a blessing that the Shimazu have sent so many warriors. We shall now show them how we can fight!
It is good to see so many Shimazu banners floating on the breeze. They are a worthy addition to our strength!
Our respected allies, the Shimazu clan, have sent only a few warriors to aid us. No matter, their worth lies not in simple numbers.
I thank our Shimazu allies for their aid. They are the bravest and truest of their clan.
My thanks to the Shimazu for coming to our aid! Their numbers are few, it is true, but their spirits are mighty!
I have reports that our respected Shimazu allies are coming. Take strength from that, and look for their banners!
With good fortune, a Shimazu army should reach us. I can promise no more, but our allies are men of their word.
If we are favoured by the spirits, then a Shimazu army will come. If not, we must fight on without help.
We should thank our Takeda allies for their aid. They have sent a generous force to help us.
It is good that the Takeda have sent soldiers to aid us. Their strength is welcome here.
The Takeda are steadfast allies. I welcome their warriors, and wish them well in the battle, for they deserve their share of glory!
The mighty lords of the Takeda have sent many men to aid us. I thank them for their efforts.
I offer thanks to the Takeda clan for their forces. Their help is not counted in numbers alone, although the count is impressive!
We are honoured to have so many Takeda warriors stand with us. Their numbers are matched only by their skills in war!
It is good to see that the Takeda clan has honoured its obligation to us. I only wish they were here in greater numbers!
I offer my thanks to our Takeda allies. I am glad to see that so many brave Takeda warriors could be persuaded to come here.
We are honoured to have the Takeda stand beside us. Their numbers are few, but their skills in war are not measured by counting!
I have word that a Takeda army is approaching. Perhaps they will arrive in time, but for now we look to our own strength.
I have heard that the Takeda could reach this battle, if they march hard. Let us hope that they do come to our aid, then.
There is a chance that we will see a Takeda army on this field. They may yet come to our aid, the spirits willing!
Our Tokugawa allies have honoured the treaty, and I thank them for their presence beside you, our brave warriors.
And now I thank our Tokugawa allies. Their banners fly besides ours, and our enemies must feel some disquiet at the sight!
I salute the Tokugawa, and thank them for their aid. Our cause is strengthened by their presence here.
My thanks to our Tokugawa allies, for they have honoured the treaty most handsomely. Theirs is a noble contribution to our ranks.
I thank the Tokugawa clan for its large army. It is heartening to see so many brawny warriors at our side!
I salute our Tokugawa allies. They have sent a mighty force to our aid, and only a fool refuses help in a battle.
I thank the Tokugawa for their obvious and deep commitment to our cause. I am surprised they could spare so many men!
It is a noble thing for the Tokugawa to support us. I only wish that nobility was in greater supply today!
My respects to the Tokugawa commander. His support is valuable, although I wish he had brought more men with him!
Before this battle is done, I hope to see Tokugawa banners flying over this field. Let our allies come, even if they are late!
If the gods will it, a Tokugawa army may come to our aid. I do not promise it, but the signs are hopeful.
I hope that we will be joined by a Tokugawa army before too long. But I cannot do more than hope for now.
I am heartened that the Uesugi clan have sent warriors to our aid. They do us honour, and we should show them our worth!
My thanks to the Uesugi commander for bringing such a brave army to our aid. It is a fine and inspiring sight!
I am happy to see the Uesugi clan here in such numbers. They are true allies in war.
I am glad that we are honoured to have a strong Uesugi army stand alongside us. Their strength is great, and welcome.
It is indeed a pleasure to see so many Uesugi warriors standing ready to fight along us. I salute them all!
The Uesugi clan are worthy of every honour. They have turned out in great strength to support us!
I am glad that the Uesugi sent soldiers to our aid, but saddened that they are so few, but aid from worthy men is welcome.
It is a fine thing that Uesugi do: they support us in this fight even though it must be a strain on their clan.
I thank the Uesugi for their efforts here. I can see they have strained every sinew to put a few men into the field.
I am pleased, for I have been told an Uesugi army is on the march. Let us hope that they are swift and strong!
I have word of an Uesugi army. It marches to us, and may yet arrive before this matter is decided. If not, we fight anyway!
We can hope for an Uesugi army at some point. As to when, I cannot say. Let us hope they march as well as fight!
I am heartened to see our allies on the field. Their clan may be few in number, but their honour is without measure!
It is good to have allies on such a day. They have proved their worth and their valour already. Let us show them ours!
I thank our allies for their support. Their warriors make a fine show, and must dishearten the foe.
I am greatly heartened to see so many allies on the field. Their numbers and honour are welcome additions to our own strength.
It is good to have so many extra soldiers. Our allies have been unstinting in their support. I thank them for it!
Our allies make an excellent contribution to our strength. Our foes will grow tired of counting their banners!
I am grateful for the aid sent by our allies. Their numbers are few, it is true. So: their share of glory will be great.
I salute our allies. Their clan has sent what men it could spare, and for that I am grateful.
Our allies have done their best. Their men are welcome: doubly so because they are few. Their share of glory will be great indeed!
I have reports to hand that our allies are coming to our aid! Until they arrive, we must rely on our own efforts.
There is a chance that we will have allies before the day is done! I promise nothing, save that they are marching!
Our allies are marching to our aid. Unless they are unlucky or go astray, we can expect their help soon, I hope.
I see the Ashikaga have sent aid to our enemies. Their numbers are superficially impressive, but they are only Ashikaga and so less than other men.
I am disappointed that the Ashikaga stand alongside our foes. They are a clan who should have more sense of decency, and honour.
I do not like to see Ashikaga banners alongside those of our enemies. But there is nothing to be done about it: they must die as well!
I see that the treacherous Ashikaga have chosen to support our enemies, and in great numbers. They are carrion birds, looking to feast!
I curse the Ashikaga lord who decided to interfere in our affairs! They dare send troops to support our enemies! The impudence of these men!
It is extremely vexing of the Ashikaga to make such a show of support for our enemies! Their numbers are excessively insolent, to say the least!
Our foes have Ashikaga allies for this fight! The Ashikaga show unexpected wisdom to send but a few warriors to the coming slaughter!
I am glad to see that the Ashikaga show restraint in their support for our enemies. I think, perhaps, they must have doubts about their allies.
I see, then, that our foes have a contingent of Ashikaga warriors with them: enough, perhaps, to make a few wives and mothers weep.
I have reports that the enemy await an Ashikaga army! I hope that Bishamon and all the spirits under his mastery will hinder their every step!
Our enemies, I am sure, have hopes that an Ashikaga army will soon appear! Let them hope for rescue! It is a womanly thing to do!
I am told that an Ashikaga army is coming to help our enemies. If they manage to find the battle, the Ashikaga can be witnesses to our victory.
I see that the Chosokabe support our enemy, and in goodly numbers too. This is a pity.
So, the Chosokabe, the trusting, easily-fooled Chosokabe, have chosen to support our enemies. This is a pity.
I see the Chosokabe are in the field. They are a simple folk, and probably do not understand that they are aiding fools.
Our enemies include many Chosokabe warriors. They are brave fighters, but fools in their choice of friends.
I am disappointed in the Chosokabe. They stand with our enemies, and in surprising numbers. I had thought them honest men.
I am tired out counting Chosokabe banners! Our enemies have far too many allies for my liking!
I see that the Chosokabe have satisfied their honour by sending but a few warriors to support our foes.
I see the Chosokabe are with our foes. Perhaps it is shame or embarrassment, but I do not count many Chosokabe banners.
Are those Chosokabe banners I see? Are they not ashamed to offer our foes such desultory aid? I would be, in their position!
According to reports, the Chosokabe are marching here to join our enemies. I had hoped for better wisdom from them.
A Chosokabe army is marching here, to support our enemies. Hopefully, they will go astray, like a carelessly shot arrow.
I have reports that our foes expect support from the Chosokabe. I also hear that the Chosokabe get lost on their way to the privy!
Besides our enemies you will see a Date army. They have honour enough to meet their obligations, then, even to the unworthy.
I see that our foes have fierce friends, if the Date can be trusted as friends. They are a clan loyal to themselves alone!
So then, our enemies have the support of the Date. I suppose I should be scared, but why should I bother to fear the Date?
I see many Date banners over there. I had not realised our foes thought themselves so weak, to need so many allies.
You will see that the Date have joined our enemy in great numbers. What of it? Their reputation is overblown.
The Date clan, then, value their alliance with our enemies. It is not like them to risk their own men in such numbers.
So, the Date support our enemies. But they are half-hearted, I see: I do not count many of them on the field.
You will see that the Date have honoured their obligations, but without enthusiasm. They are a gesture of support, not an army.
I see that Date show their true colours as merchants. They set the value their alliance with our foes at only a few men.
You may have heard that a Date army is marching towards us. They mean to aid our enemies, the swines.
Our foes are praying that their allies come in time, but I have never heard of the Date over-exerting themselves for others!
I am sure our foes are praying for help. A Date army is supposedly marching to their support. Perhaps the Date will come. Perhaps.
I see that our enemies have Hattori allies. I am surprised: I thought the Hattori favoured the tanto used in the shadows, not an honest fight!
So, our enemies have Hattori allies. I knew our enemies had dubious morals, but I did not realise they would sink so low.
Over there, you can see Hattori banners. I am surprised. The Hattori have grown impudent, for they normally prefer skulking in the shadows.
Our foes have friends, then: I see Hattori banners over there! And far too many of them for my liking. No matter! They are scum.
I am saddened to see so many Hattori warriors alongside our foes. I had hoped that our enemies had some care for their honour.
Over there you will see many Hattori banners. So our enemies have allies: think nothing of it! They are worthless mountain bandits, not warriors!
I see our foes have allies, if such creatures as the Hattori can be called "friends". They are treacherous beasts, not honourable warriors.
So, I see a few Hattori aid our enemies. This is strange: usually they come only to pick over the dead, like stinking carrion birds.
I see the Hattori have sent some warriors to aid our foes. And with typical Hattori generosity, they have sent as few as they could!
I hear the Hattori march to support our enemies. If the Hattori are involved, who can say what is really happening? Will they come?
Those notorious murderers, the Hattori, are coming to aid our foes. I will believe that when I see it, for the Hattori only help themselves!
I have reports that the Hattori are marching to help our enemies. Let them come! If they arrive, what use are such dishonourable men?
The Hojo have chosen to stand beside our foes, and in some strength. Why? What honour do they gain? I am mystified.
I see the Hojo are being honourable to a fault. They seem sincerely committed to our foes' cause.
The Hojo, then, are men of their word. They stand alongside our foes, even though they must feel the dishonour in the act.
I see that the Hojo have kept their word, and stand alongside our foes. I weep that so many warriors will meet death shortly.
I see that Hojo honour has outweighed Hojo common sense. Why else would they send so many men to support our foes?
The Hojo are indeed honourable, but beyond honour is foolishness! They have sent far too great a force to aid our foes!
The Hojo, I see, support our foes. But they do so half-heartedly, with few men, as though ashamed of their friends.
The Hojo, I see, are satisfying their honour, but little else. They have sent only a few men to support our foes!
I imagine our enemies are most unhappy to see so few of their Hojo allies in the field. But so what? Hojo honour is satisfied.
I hear that a Hojo army may yet appear and aid our enemies. Perhaps they will get lost on the way!
A Hojo army is marching to our enemies' aid. That will be enough for Hojo honour. Whether they arrive or not will be immaterial.
The Hojo are, apparently, on their way to support our foes. Perhaps the effort, rather than arriving, will be enough for Hojo honour.
So, the vicious Mori choose to support our enemies. I hope they all die ignoble deaths! Dysentery would be a fitting end!
If the Mori are aiding our enemies, they must have been promised all the loot in our baggage train. Nothing else would persuade them!
I see Mori banners among the enemy. So be it: our foes must rely on pirates and robbers for support.
I am surprised that the Mori could tear themselves away from their piratical ways for long enough to aid our foes. And in such numbers!
I think our foes must have lied to the Mori. Perhaps they promised them much booty from our corpses! That would explain their numbers!
I see many Mori banners over there. I wonder what profit they see in helping our foes to such an extent?
So, the Mori have remembered to support our allies. But they have sent barely enough men to fill a fishing boat!
I see a few Mori banners over there. I suppose the rest of them must be busy robbing fishermen rather than helping their allies!
The Mori, then, have chosen to aid our enemies. I am not impressed by a few pirates, thieves and fisherfolk!
I hear that the Mori are marching to aid our foes. Perhaps they will get here, unless their thieving ways slow them!
Our foes are waiting for a Mori army to appear and, I presume, save them. Let them wait for ten thousand years!
Our foes hope to see a Mori army come marching to their support, if the Mori can stop their thievery for long enough to help.
The Oda clan have sent men to support our foes. They will be disciplined, I am sure, and will bear watching.
So, the Oda have come to the aid of our enemies. I am disappointed, but not concerned. They will die like other men.
Our foes have aid from the Oda clan. Do not count their banners now. Wait, and count their heads later!
I see that the Oda clan are here and in great numbers. I am surprised. The Oda way is not to help, but to command!
There are many Oda warriors among our enemies today. Some would say too many, but I think we will grow bored counting their heads!
There are far too many Oda warriors with our foes. We are so dangerous that one clan alone dare not stand against us!
The Oda clan support our enemies, but their faith in the cause can be judged by their lack of numbers.
I see the Oda have sent a few fools to help our foes. After the battle, put their heads in a separate pile!
I see there are a few Oda warriors with our enemies. I do not think they will make much difference to the outcome.
I am told that the Oda clan are marching to support our foes. Perhaps they will come, but they rarely follow the orders of others.
Our enemies hope to see an Oda army before the day is done. There must be no one left alive to help!
I believe our enemies hope for aid before the battle is decided. It might be that the Oda come to help, or it might not.
I counted the Shimazu allies of our foes. It is a handsome number, but not one that we will dwell on!
There are Shimazu banners among those of our enemy. No matter: the Shimazu bleed as do other men.
The Shimazu, then, have sent our foes aid. I will not forget that. I will not forgive that.
I see the Shimazu honour their treaties, but a little too well for my liking. They have sent many men to aid our foes!
I see many Shimazu banners over there. Our enemies still have friends to die for them, apparently.
The Shimazu have been too kind to our foes. I cannot believe they have sent so many men to help them. It is foolishness!
So, the Shimazu have done as little as possible to honour their obligations. Good, for anything that weakens the foe is welcome!
I see the Shimazu sent a few of their dogs to aid their friends. Their numbers, like their value, are not impressive.
I see a few Shimazu banners over there. Our enemies have some help but not, as I judge it, very much help.
The Shimazu are marching towards this battle, to the aid of our enemies. Pray, then, that they go astray!
I am told that the Shimazu are marching towards us. Our enemies really do need help to face us!
Our enemies are praying that the Shimazu come. I pray that the Shimazu get lost, fall down a ravine or spend the day drunk!
So then, observe the Takeda warriors over there among our enemies. They are cunning, and will bear close watching.
I see our foes are supported in some numbers by those mountain monkeys, the Takeda.
There are Takeda banners over there. The horse-lovers must have been drunk when they agreed to come to this fight!
I see that our foes have Takeda allies. The horse-lords of that clan are crafty warriors, and bear careful watching in the fight to come.
So then, the Takeda have left their mountains to stand alongside our foes. I hope the Takeda women will weep when we are done!
I am surprised to see so many Takeda banners over there. Our foes are not worthy of such aid or, indeed, any aid at all!
I see there are Takeda forces in the field. Judging from their insiginifcant numbers, they have enormous faith in our enemy's cause.
The Takeda stand with our foes. It is fortunate that few of their ladies will be widowed. I do not like to hear women wail!
I see that the Takeda have had the grace to aid their allies, if so few warriors can be counted as a help in battle!
Word has come that the Takeda horse-lords are marching to this fight. If they come they will die, if I have any say.
The Takeda are supposedly coming to our enemies' aid. I pray they will be dogged by misfortune at every step!
I am sure our foes are praying that the Takeda come soon. That might happen, but if it does, we can kill horse-lovers as well!
So then, the Tokugawa have honoured their allies by sending an army. I had thought they possessed more common sense.
There are Tokugawa troops beside our enemies. The Tokugawa never do anything to help others, so why are they here?
I see our foes stand beneath Tokugawa banners. So, they have aid in this battle. I am sad they lacked the courage to stand alone.
Over there are too many Tokugawa warriors to simply show support. They have a deeper, darker purpose, and should be watched.
There are many Tokugawa over there. I wonder why they have sent so many to support their pathetic allies. What do they gain?
I see our foes are accompanied by many Tokugawa warriors. It is good that children have adults to look after them!
The Tokugawa have shown how much they honour our enemies. Look at how few men they have sent to die for them.
Our enemies, then, have faithful friends. As I count their men, I see the Tokugawa obviously value the alliance!
Our enemies obviously need help... Ah, I see they have a few men of the Tokugawa clan with them.
There is a chance that a Tokugawa army may reach this fight before the end. If they come, we will destroy them!
Our enemies expect Tokugawa aid. I think the Tokugawa will let our foes do most of the dying before they bother to intervene.
I have heard our enemies expect a Tokugawa army to march onto the field. I pray that their expectations are entirely false!
I see that our enemies have been joined by a good number of Uesugi warriors. Their powers of persuasion must be better than I thought!
The Uesugi support our foes. I am sorry for it, because I thought the Uesugi wise. Perhaps they were, once.
I am saddened to see our foes have allies. I had thought the Uesugi better than this, but I was wrong. They deserve death.
I see our foes have persuaded the Uesugi to die for them, and in great numbers. Ah, I pity the Uesugi, to be so used.
The Uesugi have great faith in their allies, to send men in such numbers. Poor fools, their faith is misplaced.
There are too many Uesugi banners among those of our enemies. I had not thought them so committed to their so-called allies.
Ah! So, the Uesugi have been persuaded to honour their treaties, but only in the most desultory fashion.
The honourable Uesugi stand with our enemies. Honourable, yes, but not quite foolish, for they have not sent very many men to die.
Our foes are honoured by having Uesugi allies. Honour is about the only support so few men can provide!
I have reports that the Uesugi intend to interfere in the battle, and support our enemies. Let us hope they go astray!
There are reports of an Uesugi army nearby. I trust they will find other, pressing matters and not interfere in our affairs.
I am told that our foes expect an army of Uesugi allies to appear. I pray their hopes will be dashed.
Our foes have some friends to stand with them, I see. No matter. I can kill worthless fools just as well as other men!
I see our foes have friends, if such creatures can be called thus. They are of no great clan, and signify almost nothing.
So, our foes have friends. But while their numbers are substantial, their value is questionable. They are not important in the affairs of Japan.
I see the foe are well supplied with allies, even if they are worthless dung who should have stayed in their middens. What fools!
Our enemies have many friends, I see. But what kind of men are they? The scruffy followers of a minor farmer, I think.
Over there our foes have many allies, from a clan of little importance and less honour. Each of them is worth less than your sandals!
I see our enemies have a few allies to stand beside them. It is pathetic, but they can do no better. I pity their widows.
Who are those beggar-like fellows standing alongside our foes? Must we kill every wastrel and jumped-up farmer who fancies himself a warrior?
I cannot understand why our enemies dishonour themselves by having such allies, and in such pathetic quantity. Where is their warrior pride? Or their dignity?
I am told that our enemies may yet receive aid from the worthless scum they call allies. So: we will beat them before help arrives!
Word has reached me that the enemy has allies approaching, warriors of an insignificant clan. If they come in time, they will die!
The enemy face us with the expectation that their allies are coming. Perhaps the fools will get here in time, but I pray not!
I hope, then, that we can make up for our lack of archers, by courage alone if need be.
Would that we had more archers among our number! Ah, it is better to think that enemies die just as easily when cut or stabbed!
I will not dissemble or lie to you, warriors. We lack archers. This is a weakness that our foes will try to exploit, and rightly so.
If I could change one thing, I would have fewer archers. No matter. We will shoot our foes, rather than cut them down!
I am pleased to have so many archers here. Indeed, we are so well provided with bowmen that they may yet have to fight had-to-hand!
I will not lie: this army is not perfect. We have many archers for the battle to come, and this may prove a weakness rather than a strength.
We are ill-prepared in only one thing: we lack artillery. Our efforts to destroy the enemy must be redoubled.
Having made the necessary calculations, I say we have too little artillery. We must be wary of keeping the enemy at a distance.
I must confess one thing: we lack artillery. I am sure the general over there will see this, and try to exploit this failing.
We need worry over only one thing: we have too much artillery to hand. Guns are good, but harmony and proportion are more welcome.
Having made the necessary calculations, I say we have too much artillery. We must be wary of letting the enemy come too close!
By my count, we are well provided with artillery, to the detriment of the army's harmonious balance. This may be a weakness the enemy can use.
We are fortunate, men, for this army is harmonious in all of its parts. To add, or remove, even one man would spoil the whole.
When you look around, you see comrades-in-arms. I look at our army and see it is a thing perfectly crafted to its purpose.
I would not change a single thing in this army, save perhaps to double it in size. All its parts make a harmonious whole.
We have too few cavalry for my liking. It means that I must be cunning in my strategies, and you must be resolute.
I would prefer to have more cavalry under my command. They are the swift stroke of the sword, that cuts off an enemy's head!
We have one lack in our ranks: we do not have enough cavalry. We cannot swiftly cut down the enemy, and their general will have seen this.
I hope that our cavalry will all find enough work on the field! I fear that their great numbers will frighten the foe too much!
Cavalry are a fine thing in moderation. They are the swift arrow, fired at the enemies heart. But a man also needs a sword.
I am a practical man where battle is concerned! This army is a fine thing, but it is not perfect: fewer cavalry would improve our harmony.
We are fortunate indeed to have such excellent archers in our ranks. Such men are to be valued above pearls, for they have perfected their skill!
Among our archers are the finest bowmen in Japan! They will hit the mark! Some have already decided which enemy eye deserves their first arrow!
I am pleased to have such expert archers under my command. I hope to give our enemies a nasty surprise, but one they will not long survive!
I salute our cavalrymen! Your skills are legendary, and you should be given every opportunity to earn your rightful glory!
Our cavalry include magnificent horsemen! They might have been taught to ride by the gods themselves! They will do their part if you do yours!
Among our ranks are horsemen of unsurpassed skill! I trust that the enemy have yet to notice this! They will be shocked, in their last moments!
Rightly, I have much faith in our army today! Our samurai are great swordsmen, and follow the old ways! They will triumph!
In the ranks of our samurai are men who are masters of the sword, the living embodiment of bushido. They stand ready! Follow their example!
Samurai! You are the sword, held in my fist! You will be the cutting edge! The enemy will fall before your skills and courage!
Today, we can withstand any enemy! Our spearmen possess great resolution and skill. They will be the immovable mountain beneath our feet!
Among our spearmen are men of great skill. I expect them to withstand any enemy. Watch them, and be inspired by their devotion to duty!
The spearmen in our army are masters of their weapons. Look to them! They will be the living fortress at the heart of this army!
I offer thanks to everyone who has left the fields for their enthusiasm, but would that we had more trained men in our ranks!
Many have shown great bravery in coming to fight, but bravery may not be enough! Look to those trained warriors, and be inspired!
As I look at our army I see many good, honest peasant faces! Be brave! I know you are not warriors, but you can die like warriors!
Would that we had a few more samurai in our ranks! You men are all doughty fighters, but additional strength of will is always welcome!
I do not wish a single man here gone, but samurai are the katana in the strong hand of a general! Would I had more!
Looking at our ranks, I see that if we have a weakness it is that we lack samurai. They are the strong right arm of a general, and no one can have enough!
I am pleased to see so many samurai in our ranks! You add lustre to our force! But we could also have used other troops, with other skills.
Samurai! You will be the spearpoint, thrust into the enemy! Do not let your enthusiam get the better of you! I may not have other troops to support you!
Samurai warriors! You are the beating heart of this army! It is your duty to be strong and resolute, for your numbers are great indeed.
I trust that our lack of spearmen will not be a problem in this fight. They can be a living fortress in a battle.
If we are forced onto the defensive, then we will rue our lack of spearmen. They are staunch heart of a defence!
I consider there is a lack of spearmen in this army. There is nothing to be done now, but the enemy will have seen this too.
Men: we have one small weakness. We have too many spearmen for this battle. They give us strength for defence, it is true, but battles are also won by attacking.
We have many spearmen in our army. Therefore, we have the ability to defend well. But we also need to attack! That will not be so easy.
I have counted our ranks, and I calculate that I have too many spearmen at my disposal. This is a small weakness, and our enemies may see it!
We are indeed fortunate to have noble heroes standing with us today! I look forward to the display of their prowess in battle!
Look to those heroes who stand with us! Emulate their deeds, and be heroic too! What enemy could then stand against us?
It is a humbling thing to stand alongside a hero, but remember: his heroism had a starting point. Let this battle be your first step on that road!
We are fortunate to have a lady of quality among our ranks. Such grace and beauty should be treasured! Such skill should be admired!
Do not be foolish and think that a lady among us has not earned here place. Anyone who stands with us does so on merit!
We are most fortunate! Look! We have a heroine here among us! She will surely strike down our enemies with fury and grace!
I am pleased to have so many expert musketeers under my command. You will not lack for targets today!
We are blessed by fortune to have expert musketeers among our number! These men will strike down our enemies, of that I am sure!
Among our musket-armed soldiers are men whose expertise is second to none! I hope the enemy do not realise this until it is too late!
Today, we have a hidden dagger, our ninja, ready to stab the enemy. In war, only the winner writes a history, and records matters of honour.
Some generals will tell you that secrecy is dishonourable in battle. Nonsense! Real dishonour lies in losing! I am glad we have ninja here!
All men in this army will do their duty, but some must work in mist and shadows. I will talk no further of this matter!
Take heart, men! We have many ninjas in our ranks today. They are the hidden dagger, aimed at the hearts of our foes!
I am delighted to have so many ninjas under my orders. Others may scoff at the "dishonour", but victory is all that matters here.
Fortune has favoured me, for there are many ninjas among us. Our enemies claim that cunning is dishonourable, but this is the spoilt whining of children!
So, our strength is well matched! This may be a hard battle. Courage, good generalship and obedience to orders will win it, not mere numbers.
I see that our foes just about match our strength. Well then, my warriors, perhaps the courage of a single man will win the day!
Let no man think our foes overmatch us today! They do not! But we do not have the advantage either! Courage will win the day!
Do not let the enemy's lack of numbers fool you. They have much strength in their ranks, and no little courage, so we will need ours today.
Over there, the ranks of the enemy look weak. This is a trick, for I tell you that they are mightier men than you might think.
Our enemy look few, but numbers do not tell us everything. I say that they are to be respected for their strength, even as we cut them down.
When the time comes, be resolute. Cut your way into the enemy ranks, then strike all around! Do not consider their numbers. They do not matter.
I see their strength and numbers are impressive. This will be a hard fight, but I tell you: it will be one worth the winning!
Our foes make a brave show, but do not be disheartened. Though we are outnumbered, we have honour to sustain us in this testing time!
So, numbers do not always deceive, for I see that they have no stomach for this fight. They are fewer than us, and weaker.
Their numbers give some indication of their strength, their resolve. They are lacking in all these, and we will take advantage of this simple truth.
Their general is a confident man, for he is outnumbered and outmatched by your prowess. Even so let us not be overconfident, only victorious.
Do not let the number of our foes deceive you. Few of them are your equals, and I would hazard a guess that none are better men.
So, I see that they outnumber us! So what? I stand with true warriors, men with iron in their souls. They are weaklings, worthless to a man.
I did think to count the enemy, but it will be easier once they are dead! Their numbers mean nothing, for they have weak hearts.
The enemy have been unwise. They should have brought more archers. Their ranks are not harmonious, and we can exploit this.
By my count, our foes lack archers. This is good, and a weakness to be ruthlessly exploited! Why should I fight fairly against fools?
My opponent lacks military wisdom. Good strategy should tell him to employ more archers on this field, but he does not. This is foolishness.
The enemy army is unbalanced, I think. There are many, many archers in the ranks. Too many for my taste, and it weakens the whole.
The enemy have some trick in mind. They have many archers: too many, in some ways. They have a cunning plan, or they are foolish.
Our foes have been foolish, for their army is not harmonious. They have too many archers in their ranks. This is not strength, but weakness!
The enemy commander has failed before he has begun. Perhaps he values tradition more than wisdom, but he has not brought enough artillery to the fight!
I have counted their artillery, and I consider it wanting! This is most heartening! A foe who cannot arrange their army properly cannot fight properly!
I do not think our enemies have given enough thought to their army. It lacks artillery, and this weakness may be its undoing.
I see the enemy general has a taste for heavy weapons. I cannot believe it is sensible to have so much artillery at your disposal!
My opponent's strategy must be very deep. He has much artillery at his command. Why so many, I cannot say. He is clever, or a great fool.
The enemy seem to have a ridiculous fondness for artillery! Such machines do not win battles alone! Men win battles! This is their weakness!
I salute the enemy general for his wise choice of troops. He has selected his men with a craftsman's eye to their proper usage.
That army over there is a perfect thing, crafted by a master. Each part fits with every other, in a killing harmony.
Our foes are cunning indeed. Their soldiers are carefully chosen, and each man knows his place and duty, I am sure.
Ah! I think I see a weakness in their ranks. Perhaps we can exploit it! They have not brought many horsemen to this battle.
The general yonder does not like horses, if my count of his troops is correct. He has not brought enough cavalry to this fight!
By my count, I think our enemies lack cavalry. They may not react quickly to our actions, and this is a weakness we can exploit mercilessly!
Perhaps our foes hope to trample us to death! I can think of no other reason why they should need quite such a large cavalry force.
I do not understand my opponent's strategy here. Why have so many cavalry? Horsemen alone do not win battles: they must have adequate support.
The enemy army is wrongly arranged. They have too many horsemen at their disposal. They make a brave sight, but they subtract from the whole!
The enemy have many skilled archers in their ranks. Long years of practice make sure men deadly, and we would do well to respect them. And kill them.
Our enemies have mighty archers with them. These men are rightly respected. They die like lesser bowmen, though, at the touch of a sword!
I see that our enemy has brought some skilled bowmen to this battle. Well, no matter! We fight in any storm: rain, snow or arrows!
The general over there is wise! He has some excellent cavalry to hand! We must make sure this mighty sword is blunted before it is used!
I do not like to see so many horsemen of quality riding with our enemies. However skilled, though, their worth is lessened by the foolishness of my opponent!
Our foes have many exceptional horsemen in their ranks. We must be careful to make sure they have the chance to become exceptional corpses!
I see that our enemies include some mighty samurai warriors. Treat these men with caution, but do not fear them. They die like ordinary men.
There are many mighty samurai among the enemy. It is good to face worthy opponents, for honour grows with each one that we defeat!
There are great samurai warriors standing in the enemy ranks. I do not like to think of so many honourable men being killed for so paltry a cause.
We must be careful how we attack! I see that our enemies have brought some masters with the spear to the battle. They will be dangerous.
I see that some of the enemy spearmen are skilled and dangerous. Remember, though: no man is immovable, and all can die!
There are, among our foes, some spearmen of the most expert kind. Be wary when you face these men, for they will surely be a danger!
I see that our foes are well supplied with peasants. There is little honour for us in their slaughter, but it does make the day's work easier.
By my count, the enemy are adequately supplied with farmers, untouchables and peasants. They lack warriors, but I do not intend to worry about that!
Our foes are mostly peasants, I see. This is a foolish thing, for them to have so many untrained rabble in their ranks. It will be their downfall!
My opponent is a man who under-values his samurai, if I count his men correctly. He weakens his force, and we will take full advantage!
The harmony of the enemy army has not been properly calculated by their general. He has neglected his samurai. His forces suffers for it.
There are too few samurai over there! This is not the boast of a samurai, but a statement of fact. Their lack weakens the enemy! Excellent!
I see the enemy have great faith in their samurai. Good for them! I am a practical man, and think their army unbalanced because of it!
Our foes have many samurai in their ranks. They are worthy indeed, but our enemies are weakened by too many of them!
A masterful commander does not rely on one sort of warriors. He masters the uses of all. My opponent has too many samurai in his force!
The enemy then, have made a mistake in their arrangements. They are noticeably lacking in spearmen. How do they hope to hold a line?
Just as a good meal includes rice, fish and spices, an army needs its right ingredients. By my count, the enemy have too few spearmen.
My opponent is either a genius or a fool. I think the latter, perhaps. Why else would he neglect to bring sufficient spearmen to this fight?
Our enemies obviously place a great value on spears. I do not think they have studied strategy, to have quite so many!
The general yonder is obviously easily impressed by the size of a man's weapon. That explains why he needs quite so many spearmen!
I see our foes have come prepared to defend and hold us at bay. Why else bring so many yari to this fight? But attacking wins battles!
Our foes have some notable heroes in their ranks, and I salute them. I also mourn, for they will die defending a most unworthy cause.
There are banners among the enemy belonging to worthy heroes. It is a pity that such men must die soon.
There are worthy heroes fighting for our enemies. For shame! Have they no honour, that they stand with our foes? Whores! Not heroes!
Do not treat any lady among the enemy lightly. She will be a mighty warrior in her own right. Instead then: honourably strike her down.
There are women in the enemy ranks! Women! So, our foes need to hide behind ladies rather than do their own fighting!
I see our foes have brought their mothers with them to spank us! Or perhaps it is their whores to pleasure us to death!
Our foes are fortunate in one thing: today they have some excellent musketeers among their ranks. We must be careful with these men.
There are dangerous and skilled musketeers among our foes. We would do well to seek them out and slay them with some haste!
We must be wary of the enemies' musketeers. Some, I am sure, are men of skill and quality. Their gun fire will be deadly, if we give them easy targets.
I worry that our foes are treacherous, and have ninja among their ranks today. This is not an honourable way of war, and we must guard against it.
Our enemy are, of course, completely honourable. That is why they have brought ninja to this fight, because they value their honour so highly!
It is my belief that the treacherous swines yonder have brought ninja onto this battlefield. Their underhand methods will not prevail!
I believe that our enemies have many ninjas within their ranks. They are, of course, completely treacherous and dishonourable in doing this!
I have the suspicion that our enemies will use many ninjas in this battle. Do not fear them! For all their reputation, they bleed and die!
Our enemies are most treacherous. Their general has many ninjas under his hand. He will use them dishonourably, I am sure of it!
We fight where land and sea meet. This is never an easy thing, but once we have gained solid ground, the day will be ours, I am sure.
We must fight for dry land. Nothing else matters, for if we do not gain a good footing, all our efforts will be wasted.
With the sea at our backs we face a struggle, but it is one worthy of our mettle! We must gain dry land over the bodies of our foes!
Whoever holds the bridge will win this battle, that must be obvious to our foes. We must take it, no matter how bloody the struggle.
So, then. We must take that bridge, hold it, and then destroy our foes. This, men, will be interesting indeed, and deadly for them!
Attack on a narrow front is always risky, men. So, rich rewards for the first men over that bridge and amongst the enemy!
My orders to you are simple: we are going to take this fortress. I do not expect that it will be easy. I do expect it to be done.
My plan is simple: we batter the walls down. Failing that, we go over them. Failing that, ha! I will haunt this place for ten thousand years!
These walls look impossible to take, but they are only as strong as their defenders' will. Break that, and all will fall before you!
The defences we must take are large and impressive. The enemy hope they are enough. Against lesser men, it might well be so.
The walls here look strong, but we can take them. The defenders know this, and they fear our assault. It must be swift, merciless and implacable!
So, we attack the walls! Be resolute, wait for your chance, and then advance with speed and determination. Give the defenders no chance to hold!
This fortress is, perhaps, not as impressive as some. But do not let that fool you. Attacking an enemy behind walls is always a risky business. But we will do it!
The walls here are not impressive when you really look at them. No defender would expect to hold this place for long against resolute men.
It is no great matter to take these walls. They are only as strong as their defenders' spirits. Crush them: and down come the walls!
So, men, crossing the river is our road to victory. I will not tell you this will be easy. It will be hard, but so what?
We will cross the ford, then, and engage the foe. They will try to stop us, but I will not permit this! You will not permit this!
We must take the river, and hold it until our army is on the far bank. Only then can we look to destroy the foe.
Our enemies are sensible, defending in these hills. We must attack with resolution, but it will not be easy.
This is not be a battle for the faint-hearted! Our enemies have a good position, but we will make it a butcher's shop!
We will spend most of this battle fighting uphill. Fate will make sure of that! The enemy will always be up the next hill!
Superstitious men might worry about demons nipping at our heels, but so what? We have mortal enemies over there. Warriors face danger every day.
We have come to the field from an unfortunate direction, but I think our enemy are worried by that. They know Hell's demons march in our ranks!
Do not worry that we have approached the battle from a poor direction! Men make their own luck, and men such as you make their own good luck!
It is never easy, fighting at night. But darkness is our friend, our armour against the enemy, and we use their fears to bolster our attacks!
This is a night attack. This is a difficult thing, and you must rely on disicpline and duty at all times, or confusion will overtake us.
At night, the perfume of blossoms always seems stronger. Here, the enemy will seem fiercer. They are not! It is a trick of the dark!
Here armour will not always save you. Do not trust in armour. On this battlefield, moving quickly and engaging the enemy closely are more important.
As always, the peasants will suffer when we are done here. Their fields will be damaged, and their crops will suffer. Fight hard anyway.
We must cross the fields quickly. The poor ground will slow us, and only fools like marching in mud and paddy water!
The trees and woods are both opportunity and problem. We can approach the enemy under cover, but they can treacherously hide there.
Do nothing to offend the kodama! The tree-spirits are unforgiving to the disrespectful, and we can use the trees to hide our intentions from the enemy.
We go to attack the enemy, but carefully. These trees can hide many foes, and the spirits will remember if we are disrespectful!
Our foes are unlucky in their choice of approach! We shall give them more reasons to fear us than anything that might be chasing at their heels!
I see our foes are not superstitious! It is their ill luck to face us, and today we must be hell-spawned monsters, not men!
Our foes are not superstitious men, or they are fools. Demons must have followed them. Keep watch, and let hell-spawn feast on our enemies!
When we have finished this battle, I want the tide to be red with enemy blood. And I will have crabmeat with my rice when I celebrate tonight!
We must leave the sands red with our enemies' blood, and the gulls sick at the taste of flesh! Only then will we have done our duty.
Here we should not allow our foes above the high tide mark. Let them drown in the shallows, and feed the crabs!
Let us be clear: we will hold the bridge here, even against hell-spawned demons if they come against us. Fortunately, today we fight mere men!
Much of our work today will be in preventing the enemy from crossing the bridge. They must pay in blood for every step they take!
That we defend a bridge crossing is a benefit. The enemy can only come at us that way, and in small numbers.
This place is strong! Indeed, a man would have to go far to find its like in these islands! Therefore, we must be worthy of the place, and be strong too.
We will hold these walls even if every Hell-born demon comes against us. But we face only men, so I am not overly concerned!
Our walls are mighty but they are not impregnable! Only the defenders' stout hearts make a fortress unconquerable. The matter is in our hands!
These walls are the work of many hands. Men toiled so that we might have defences today. I do not intend to have their labours wasted!
These walls are mighty, but they are useless without mighty men to defend them. You are those men! As long as you stand, so do these walls!
We need only be true in our hearts as we stand on these ramparts. Let the enemy dash themselves to pieces, a futile storm that means nothing!
These walls may not be mighty but our hearts must make up for their shortcomings. We stand as one and we will prevail!
Here we are the main defence. Do not think that the walls will keep the enemy out! That is our part in what is to come!
Walls do not make a fortress. Men are a fortress! Today we are the fortress! No living enemy will take the fortress! I swear it!
This battle will be decided by one thing: all the strategies in the world will count for nothing if we allow the enemy to cross the river unopposed.
We must not let the enemy cross the ford! Instead, we must make sure it becomes their grave, and the waters run red with their blood.
We will not let the enemy cross the river! If we do our duty, the fish will feed well for days on our fallen foes!
There are worse places in battle than in these hills. Let our foes wear themselves out coming to us. Then they will fall to our blades!
Let our foes come! Marching in armour is always wearisome, and doubly so over hills. We shall let tired men come to their deaths!
We will hold these hills, and let our enemies tire themselves be scrambling up to meet us! The higher ground always favours the defenders!
Battles at night are always confusing, so trust your commanders. Our success depends on discipline, and anticipating the enemies' intentions.
Do not fear the night. In darkness, our enemies will go astray and their plans miscarry. Darkness is our fortress!
Defence is best at night. There is no need to stumble around like a drunken fool, looking for a man to fight. But keep quiet!
The ground here favours the defence. This is good for us. The mud will slow our foes, and tire them before the first blow is struck.
It is hard work walking through fields. Ask any peasant! Our foes must come to us across wet ground. Good. They will be tired when they arrive!
This ground is good! Our foes will weary themselves just by marching across it, and tired men are easy to kill!
I like these woods. Trees have long lives, and remember things men do not. If we treat them with respect, they will hide our intentions from the enemy.
These trees are most excellent. We can use them as cover. I apologise in advance to the kodama for our enemies' poor manners.
These trees have stood here for a long time. Treat them kindly, even as you use them for cover, and watch for the enemy hiding among them!
I see that the spirits have cursed us with rain and made our guns useless. Well, the same is true for the enemy. The old ways are best!
We cannot rely on gunners or archers in this rain! So, then, we look our foes in the eye as they die!
I do not know whether to curse this rain, or praise it. We must rely on courage, then, and the sword, not the gun!
This rain is most unfortunate! We cannot rely on our guns, so I look to your courage instead.
I curse these rain clouds! Our guns are useless in this foul weather, and this damp always saddens my soul. I suppose we must endure it.
Curse this rain! We must rely on our swords, and the old ways. I had hoped to shoot our foes down like mad dogs.
This rain is most welcome, although I hate being wet and cold as much as any man! It is their guns, you see: they are useless in the rain!
This rain is excellent. It may make you wet, cold and miserable, but it stops the enemy from using their cursed guns! I thank the heavens for it!
Our foes rely on guns, and rain is the great enemy of guns! Now we will cut them down, and the rain will wash away their blood.
This is a fine day. The breeze is gentle, and all that is lacking are the peaceful notes of a flute floating upon it.
This weather is most welcome. It reminds me of childhood days. If one is to fight a battle, then what can be finer than a day like this?
This is a day to fill the soul of a warrior with joy! A battle, an adversary, and gentle breezes to cool the brow!
This mist is both good and bad. It hides us from the enemy but we must beware their trickery. Keep a sharp watch.
Most excellent! These mists are the gifts of clever spirits. They hide us from the enemy, and mask our actions with a gentle deception.
Do not let the mists dampen your spirits! They are no more than the fan that hides a shy lover's smile. They will hide us as well!
I do not like this rain! It saps a man's strength and worse, it slows bowmen in shooting. No matter, we shall fight them hand-to-hand. And be wet!
Before we are done, we shall be wet, and cold, and miserable. Even so, we are hardy folk, and will fare better than our enemies.
So: rain! Do not feel despair at being wet! All soldiers can do with a good wash, our enemies more than most! You will be grateful for that when they are close!
The snow is beautiful, is it not? Such perfection should not be marred by bloodstains and brawls. Our enemies, however, insist on so doing.
The snow hides much ugliness. It is regretable that we must be disrespectful and spoil so much purity and beauty with blood and battle.
There is something clean about snow! I like it! My heart, though, is heavy because our actions today will wipe away this beauty.
A storm! Who in their right minds wants to fight in such weather? Our foes? No! So, let us use madness and fight!
This weather is the work of Raijin! If it is unpleasant for us, it is the same for our foes. So we fight anyway!
I am sure the enemy give thanks to the spirits for this weather, but it is no reason to spare them the sword's edge!
The enemy are cowards! They have treacerously mined these waters! They dare not meet us in an honest fight, like men! They are filth!
I do not like our foes' methods. They have little honour and less courage if they are using mines! They are cowards' weapons!
The wave-spirits will curse our foes today! They are craven monsters, to use sea-mines and so offend the spirits! Even the fish will curse them!
Our enemies are fools! They have put themselves in a poor position. With us to windward and a shore beyond them, they are trapped!
I see our foes are not seamasters, but only fools! Why else would they have the rocky shore in their lee, ready to destroy their vessels?
It may not be honourable, but driving our foe onto the shore will defeat them as surely as any swordplay. Ah, victory is what counts!
There are risks to fighting at night, but sometimes danger can be made part of a battle plan. That is what I intend: darkness is our friend!
At night discipline and good order are doubly important. The darkness hides our actions from the foe, but will confuse the unwary among us.
We must be vigilant and attentive! A sea battle is always confusing; a night attack at sea is a true test of our great abilities!
We attack! We attack! We attack! That is the only strategy worth considering. We do not need to worry about wind or waves!
Wind and wave are favourable to our cause! The spirits have blessed these waters, ready for our victory!
Sea spirits! I ask you, in all humility, to calm the waves! We will do the rest, and give you a battle worth the watching!
We must be wise seamasters, not rash landsmen. There are hidden dangers beneath the waves, and I do not want to be a shark's dinner today!
Beware the rocks and dangerous shallows! They are traps for our enemies, not us. Let them feed the crabs if they are careless!
I have reports that the seas here are treacherous and shallow. We must be vigilant, for a ship aground is a ship lost to the enemy!
Today the sea gods have smiled on us! I see that we out-gun the enemy. Very well, let us blow them to pieces and feed the fishes!
I think we carry more guns than the enemy in our fleet! This is most excellent! Let us send them to the depths with iron cruelty!
Let our foes approach! I am confident that our gunners will destroy their vessels and send them to the deeps before they can harm us!
I have sown the seas with mines! Let the enemy come to us! They will be blown to smithereens, and die as fish bait!
Our foes will curse the wave-spirits! They will think that even the sea hates them, if the mines we have used do their work well!
I ask the spirits of wave and winds to move our mines towards our enemies. Let us destroy them however we can!
Our position here is a strong one, but we must watch the wind! Carelessness could see brave ships beached, or on the rocks!
We must watch the wind and waves, for the shore is to our lee! For fighting men, such things do not matter. To sailors they are vital!
Even as the enemy come at us, we must not give up sea room! To be driven back onto the shore would seal our fate!
We must be wary, for darkness will be a friend to our enemies. They will use the cover of night to approach and attack!
A battle at night is always risky, but doubly so for the attacker. They must manoeuvre in the dark: I trust they will fail in this test!
Let the enemy take foolish risks! They have to come to us and, if they are not good sailors, disaster in the dark may befall them!
These waters have no dangers, I see. We must rely on ourselves alone to defeat the foe, not the hazards of wind and waves!
Wind and wave favour neither side here! This will be a test of courage and seamanship. Let us be sure we have a surplus of both!
Let our enemy come! The sea will not help them! The spirits of these waters surely favour our cause, if there is any justice in them!
There are dangerous rocks and shoals here. Good! Perhaps we can persuade our enemies to go aground, and drown! I do not care how they die!
I intend to use the shoals and hidden rocks to our advantage! Let the enemy come to us, let them founder and drown!
An enemy who is slain because he drives his ship onto the sunken rocks hereabouts is as dead as one who dies by my sword!
We are unlucky, for our foes have more guns than we do. We must, then, fight them in the old ways, hand-to-hand, with courage, not gunpowder!
I calculate our enemies outgun us somewhat. They mean to blow us out of the water then, rather than fight like men!
I count many guns on the enemy fleet: more than we carry, I fear. No matter! We shall close with them, and fight at close quarters!
A fine day: I see our banners fly proudly in the breeze. The spirits of the deep are calm! All we need now is victory!
Wave-spirits, I thank you! A calm day is all we need! We will do the rest in what is to come!
So then, a good day for fishing or a ladies' pleasure cruise! We must, then, put all our efforts into fighting to ensure victory.
Ah, these mists are not sent to try us! No! We will use what the sea spirits have given us, and conceal our intentions from the enemy!
We must be careful in this mist. If we are careless the spirits will send us astray! But then, they may do the same to our foes!
These mists can hide enemy ships, and deceive the eye! Trust in yourselves and your mastery of the waves! Trust in your swords and weapons!
This rain is unfortunate: we must close on the enemy, then, and fight in the old style! No bows or guns will suffice in this weather!
I like this rain! We can fight in the old style! So close with your enemy, board, and what can then go wrong?
This rain dampens a sailor's spirits, I know. But if you are wet and miserable, pity your foes! They are the same, but without an honest cause to die for!
To fight at sea can be dangerous! To fight in this weather, worse! No matter. Let the enemy fear us, not a few snowflakes!
A snowstorm is hardly fit weather for a battle, but we must endure it. For myself, I would sooner be ashore with a warm woman!
Wind and waves and snow! Not even a gull would be stupid enough to fly today and yet, here we are, fighting some extremely foolish men!
Men! This is no weather for a battle, but we take what Raiden gives us! If the storm hampers us, think what it is doing to our foes!
Storms are no fit place for warriors at sea, but fight we must! If we run, the enemy will claim we fled from them! So, let us to it!
There is much danger in this storm! Soldiers! Listen to the sailors and ships' captains! Do their bidding willingly, and all will be well!
The spirits have not always been kind to me in battle, but I feel this is about to change. Today, I feel we can win!
Some among you may doubt me, but do not! I have had ill-luck in battle, but I have all the talents of a general.
In the past I have been dealt a poor hand in battle, but not today, I feel sure. You are the men to carry out my plans successfully!
I have not always been lucky in my battles, but with men such as you under my leadership, I lack for nothing today!
I will be honest with you: I am not always a lucky general. But I do try to be a brave one who does his duty.
I always try to win my battles! I am not always favoured by fortune but today, with your help, I think we can win.
I know that I have not fought many battles as a commander, but I will do my utmost for victory. Be sure you do the same!
Some men say that I am inexperienced! Nonsense! The art of command is more than simply counting a man's battles!
I have heard mutterings from some that I have not commanded many armies. This is true! But those men I have lead always remember me!
Take heart from my experience, men. I have rarely lost a fight, and I do not intend to lose today! But why should I, with you under my command?
I have fought and won many battles. Today, I will add to my tally of victories. And you will have tales to tell your grandchildren!
Today I wish to remain a stranger to defeat. I think that you will prove worthy in the field, and all will be well.
I will not lie: I like winning battles. I do it from time to time, and it is far more satisfying than defeat.
The spirits are often kind to me in battle. Today will, I pray, be no different. I feel in my heart that they will help!
I have won many battles, and my ancestors have every reason to feel proud of me. Today, I intend to give them fresh cause for pride!
I know that battle is sometimes a matter of chance. It is the duty of a general to make the most of his chances and I will do so.
I have heard men say that I do not win many battles. This may be true, but I win the ones that matter!
Some have said behind my back that I lose battles. True, any general can lose a battle. But with good men, like you, I can win!
And at the last, remember you are Chosokabe! What else does a man need to know?
And now, my honest Chosokabe warriors: know that our clan is strong, and we will be strong!
And let your battle cry be "Chosokabe!" It is a proud name! Do not be afraid to use it!
Now, take up your weapons and make your last farewells. Some of you may die, but the Chosokabe will have a victory!
And now, Chosokabe soldiers, remember that the arrow flies true when shot with sincerity. Cheer! Show your courage!
And now we are like the arrow, nocked and ready for release. We shall fly at the enemy, and defeat them utterly!
Now, brave Chosokabe, put aside any thoughts except victory. Do not worry about living: advance with resolution!
And now shout your defiance at the foe, my brave Chosokabe! Soon we fight!
And now be as swift as the arrow, fired into an enemy heart! Give them no mercy, you Chosokabe heroes!
And now, you Chosokabe heroes, give a cheer and put fear in their hearts!
And at the last, remember you are Date! That alone weakens our foes!
Now, brave Date warriors, remember who you serve. Take strength from our awesome name!
And now, Date warriors, shout your hate at the enemy and give them fear!
Now, you Date, prepare yourselves, Look to your armour and weapons. Cheer, and it begins!
And remember, my Date warriors, what we do here will be the stuff of nightmares for enemies as yet unborn!
And now we must make many widows and orphans. Let them weep when they hear the name "Date", and scream when they see our banners!
So let us cheer, and hold up our banners! Let our foes see that the Date have come! Let them see their doom approach!
Now, harden your hearts and set your minds on victory! This will be a great day for the Date!
Now, you heroes of the Date, draw your swords and prepare for glory! Glory! Glory and victory!
And now, my brave Date heroes, give a fierce cheer for our clan, and for our victory to come!
And now, my worthy warriors, it is time to show them what steadfast Hattori courage and cunning Hattori strategy can do!
Now, heroes of the Hattori, prepare yourselves! Say your prayers, and let the wisdom of our ancestors guide us to victory!
And always remember, you brave Hattori, that they are afraid of every single one of you! Give them cause for their fears!
And now, remember that it is a proud thing to belong to the Hattori clan! There is nothing better in all of Japan!
So, we come to it! Remember that you are Hattori! Be worthy, and all will be well! Victory!
Be strong! Be cunning! Be cruel! War does not reward the kind or the simple-minded! It will reward us, the mighty Hattori!
Give them not a moment's rest, you noble Hattori! Carry the fight to the enemy, and all will be well!
And now, cheer! Lift up our banners, so that even the heavens can see our worth! We, the Hattori, go to battle!
And now, my Hattori warriors, remember your homes and your families! See to it that our foes never see theirs again!
Now, you noble Hattori, put aside all gentle and cultured thoughts! This is the moment for savagery, as bleak as our mountains at home!
And at the last, remember you are Hojo! It is a proud thing, and the source of your strength!
Now, stand, proud Hojo, and remember your faith, honour and duty! Be brave! Be strong!
And now, my Hojo soldiers, shout the heavens, and remind the gods why we are worthy of victory!
And now, we must go to set the world aright! Fight bravely, Hojo warriors, and victory will be our reward!
And now, we are ready. We Hojo have always been ready for victory, and today is no different!
And now, cheer you brave souls! Show your foes that the Hojo are coming for them!
Now, my brothers in arms, it is time to show our foes the meaning of Hojo courage! Make ready!
Now we will show them what Hojo courage means, and what steadfast obedience and true faith can achieve! To arms!
And now, think kindly of your loved ones. We fight for them, and our great Hojo clan! And we will prevail!
And now, Hojo warriors, prepare to be heroes! Our daimyo expects nothing less from us!
And at the last, remember you are Mori! Our cunning will serve us well!
Now, warriors of the Mori, stand fast! Remember your duty, and we will triumph!
And now, proud Mori, shout out, and turn the enemies' guts to water!
And remember, my Mori warriors, that we are cunning as well as brave. We will win, because of that!
And now, worthy soldiers of the Mori, make ready! We must show the enemy the true meaning of courage!
And now, let us show courage, and Mori courage at that! We are better than our foes in every respect!
Now, let us show these fools that the Mori do not fight with swords alone, but with cunning! Let us crush them!
Now, men, cheer, and raise up our Mori banners! Stand proudly in their shadow, and then fight like demons!
And remember: they do not have one tenth of our Mori cunning, nor one tenth of our Mori courage!
And so shortly we will fight! We will fight for our great Mori clan and, even if we die, we will serve our daimyo well!
And finally, be strong and fierce! We Oda put fear in men's hearts!
And finally, brave warriors of the Oda clan, do your best! That is enough for victory!
And now, my fierce Oda soldiers, shout your hatred at the enemy, and let them know that destruction is at hand!
And at the last, remember you are Oda warriors! That alone scares your foes more than any demon!
And remember, my brothers, that we are the stuff of nightmares to our foes! We are the Oda, and we have come for them!
And now look into your hearts and see Oda courage there. That will sustain you! Victory!
And now, cheer, and show those idiots that they face the Oda in all their might and glory!
Now, brave Oda, shout your defiance at the enemy! Show them who comes to do slaughter today!
And now, brave Oda, cheer! Let your shouted hatred be the last thing your enemies hear in this life!
And now we go to it! We Oda have never feared battle! Why should we? We are the Oda!
And at the last, be proud you Shimazu warriors! You defend the honour of a great clan!
And now, sons of the Shimazu, look to your duty and your weapons!
And now, proud sons of the Shimazu, shout out, and let the enemy realise that they face great men today!
And now look into your hearts and see Shimazu loyalty there. That strength will bring us victory!
And now let every man act like a hero! You all have it in you, you brave Shimazu warriors! Let us fight!
