And now, cheer and show those fools what great hearts beat in every Shimazu breast! Now we fight!
And now we go to battle! Remember that you are Shimazu! There is no prouder boast for a man to make!
And remember: mothers will frighten naughty children a hundred years from now with the name "Shimazu" because of what we do here!
And so now is the hour when we prove Shimazu virtue once more! It is no great test against such a foe!
And now battle comes upon us! We Shimazu are no strangers to the blade! We are born with weapons to hand! Let us use them!
And finally, remember that we are the Takeda! We fight, we die, but we are always Takeda!
And now, sons of the Takeda, stand and fight. Be as immovable in spirit as a mountain!
Now, my Takeda brothers, give a cheer. Let the enemy hear that you do not count them much of a threat!
Now, my Takeda warriors, give them a lusty, mountain cheer! Show them that we are ready and waiting to kill them!
Now, my fine Takeda soldiers, we must kill and kill again. Their deaths are necessary, if regretable.
And now hold aloft the banners of our Takeda clan! Let the foe see who comes, and let them hear your courage!
And now cheer, let the foe know doubt and fear! Deafen the fools with Takeda courage!
And now we fight! Think only of your Takeda honour, kill your foe, and all will be well!
And so to battle, my Takeda brothers! Now we prove our worth! I know that none of us will be found wanting!
And remember: what we do here will echo for a thousand years in the legends of the Takeda clan!
And at the last, remember honour, you brave sons of the Tokugawa! That is more than enough for any man!
And now, Tokugawa warriors, remember your own strength! It is the strength of our clan!
Now, my honourable Tokugawa brothers, cheer for our clan, and for their defeat! Onwards!
And at the last think carefully about what it means to be Tokugawa. We do not retreat. We do not fail!
Now, lift up our proud Tokugawa banners! Let the foe see them! Let him hear your voices, shouting in triumph!
And now to the fight! My brave Tokugawa, I will be proud to drink sake with any of you, once all our foes are dead!
And remember: enemy widows and orphans will weep when they hear the name of Tokugawa. We will prevail!
And remember: our clan will tell the story of how we Tokugawa fought for a hundred years! Give them a tale worth telling!
And now, let our foes feel terror at your battle cry! Let them never have peace as long as one Tokugawa lives this day!
And so to battle! Cheer, and give your enemy a taste of Tokugawa fury!
And remember, you sons of Uesugi, that you fight for a great and noble cause!
And now, soldiers of the Uesugi, remember that you alone are worthy to fight and die for our great clan!
And now, let them hear what angry warriors sound like! Cheer, my Uesugi warriors, and give them a fright!
And remember that we Uesugi are people with faith! That will sustain you in this battle, and give us victory!
And now cheer, and puts fear in the hearts of yonder fools! And then we Uesugi will show them how to fight!
And so the the fight! Hold on to your faith, and your honour as Uesugi! All will go well for us!
And now, let us give the storytellers and poets a tale worth the telling: how we Uesugi crushed our foes utterly!
And remember: when we are done, demons in Hell will only dare speak the name of "Uesugi" with fear! Let us have victory!
And now let your battle cry shake the heavens! Let our foes quake at the righteous fury of the Uesugi!
And now, let your cheers un-man our enemies! Let them shake in their armour at very word "Uesugi"!
And now, my brother has trusted me to win this battle! I say his trust is not misplaced, and we will win! Victory!
And finally, I know that when I speak to my brother, my voice will grow hoarse in describing all your brave deeds today. Onwards!
And I know my brother is proud of us all! Let us make him even prouder as we gain a victory here!
And finally, I dedicate this, our coming victory, to my beloved brother! I draw strength from his inspiring leadership! Onwards, to our triumph!
And now, give a cheer so loud that even my brother will hear it! Shake his cherry trees at home! Shake the enemy in their armour!
And think of this: my grandfather has trusted us to win this battle! I say his trust is not misplaced, and we will win! Victory!
And I know that when I tell my grandfather of this day, my voice will grow hoarse telling of your brave deeds. Onwards!
And I know Grandfather is proud of us all! He will be even prouder when we gain him a victory!
And finally, I would like to dedicate our coming victory to my Grandfather! We draw our strength from his inspiring leadership!
And now, give a cheer so loud that even my Grandfather will hear it! Shake the enemy in their armour!
And, at the last, think of this: one day I will lead our clan. And then I will remember brave warriors who fought today. To our victory!
And know this: I will remember those who fight with honour, and reward them in the years to come! Do your duty!
And I know that my father expects us all to fight with courage! How can we do anything else, if we call ourselves men?
And remember, I will be daimyo! When I am, I will hold a banquet, and celebrate today with pride because we will be victorious!
Remember: one day I will rule! The men who support me now should anticipate a rich future. This is the first step on a long road!
And remember: I have the honour to lead you, the finest warriors in the land. Do your duty now, and leave all else to fate!
And now, we go forth! It is a privilege to lead men such as you! Keep honour in your hearts and we will have victory here!
As your lord, I know that you will fight to your utmost. Your devotion to duty is matchless, and I am honoured to lead you today.
I can think of nothing better than to command you in battle. You are all that is good and noble about our clan! My blessings!
And when I look on your ranks, I am proud to be your daimyo. We are a great clan, worthy of the victory we shall win here.
And remember that my father expects good news! I know his heart will swell with pride when he hears of your deeds today! To victory!
And lastly, I know my father. He has every confidence in me, you, me, to win here today. I will not let him down!
And now I am eager for the fray! Today I will make my father proud that I am a warrior! To our victory!
And now, hold to your duty and all will be well! We will give my father the gift of a victory here today!
And remember: if we win today, my father will be most generous with his rewards! Loyalty will be remembered!
And remember: we are honourable warriors, with noble spirits and pure hearts! Our victory today will uphold that honour, and add to it!
I know that today you will do nothing dishonourable. I know that today you will only add to the noble history of our clan.
And remember this: we can only win more honour for our clan here today! We will fight! We will die well! We will triumph!
And remember: victory is important, but not at the cost of honour! We stand, we fight, we die if needs be for that honour!
And remember: our honour is our armour and the swords in our hands! Without it, we are nothing! With it, we cannot be defeated!
And now we shall prove to all that we are an honourable clan. Our worthy victory will add lustre and glory to our name!
And now, all is said. This is a day where we will win much honour for our clan, and our names will be forever remembered!
And remember: today the fight is about more than simple victory! We will show the world that we are men of honour!
And now, be steadfast and hold to your duties. That way is the road to honour, regardless of victory or defeat!
And think of this: there is honour in duty. Whether we live or die, our names will live if we acquit ourselves well!
And at the last, do not huddle together for supposed safety! That is not the act of a warrior, only a coward. I do not lead cowards!
And now, make your peace with your comrades. Check your armour, and put aside all worldly concerns. We go to glory and victory!
Now pray to the gods, and ask the spirits for their help. Pray to the Christian god too, for all aid is welcome in battle!
And remember: the cause we defend is a noble one! Our clan is a noble one! Do not prove yourselves base, mean-spirited or cowards!
And now, look into your hearts, and see strength there. We cannot fail, for we fight as one!
And now cheer, and terrify your worthless enemies! Un-man them, weaken their bowels, and show them to be fools for standing before us!
And at the last, think of the glory to come! Duty is very fine, but fame as a warrior is equally worthy!
And so, let us have a famous victory here! Let our names live forever! Let our cheers shake the gates of Hell!
And now, do your duty when the time comes! Do only that, and your foes will fall before you!
And now, I wish you well of the day! May your names live for ten thousand years!
And now, attend to your weapons and lace up your armour! The time is upon us! I wish you luck!
And now, I pray to the spirits that your efforts are blessed! May you all return victorious!
And so I say this at the last: some of us will fall. Some of us will live! But we will all do our duty!
And now, shout to the heavens and put fear in our enemies' hearts! Let them know that they face truly dangerous men!
And lastly, battles are not won by cowards or timid women! Men and hard fighting win battles! And I see men under my command!
And so, make your last preparations. That done: take heart, and look forward to our glorious victory!
And remember: the warrior who seeks death while his enemy lives is a fool. I do not command fools! I command you!
And now, be true to your comrades! Do your duty! That is all, and we will have victory!
So now we are ready for battle! Like all fights, this will be hard, but do not be worried. We will win!
And now, victory will shortly be within my grasp! It is an honour to lead you in this struggle!
And now put aside all weakness, any thoughts of defeat! Tonight, we will have a victory dinner, and enough sake to drown us all!
And so now I wish you well. Some of you have fought before, some have not. All that matters is that you fight now, here, today!
So, we are done with speaking. Now is the time of swords! Warriors: I wish you well of the day!
And now we stand ready to do all that is needed. If we fight for each other, we will win! And later: we celebrate!
And lastly, do not be blind in your hate of the foe! Use your wits as cleverly as your weapons! Now: use your voices!
And lastly, consider that your foes are already scared at the sight of you! Now cheer, and utterly dishearten them!
And now, shout your hate at the enemy. Let them see our bloodthirsty ways, and let them know fear!
And so we fight. Set aside all doubts, as I have done. We are proper men, and will win today!
And now we go forwards into battle. I will honour those who fall! I will reward those who give us victory!
And now to our victory celebrations! Yes, we must first fight a battle, but that hardly need trouble men such as us!
And now, we go to victory. Every man will kill his foe! Every step we take will be slippery with enemy blood!
And now, I have said enough. Words are done, and great deeds await! I wish you all good fortune!
And now it is time! Grasp your swords, your spears and your courage! We go to battle, and from there to victory!
So now, my poor oratory is over. I will do my part as commander! Do yours as dauntless warriors and we cannot fail!
So, enough of words! There is a battle to be won, and after that rewards to be given, and good sake to be savoured!
And now, remember: we are the victors here. They are the witless dead, still walking the earth! Let us send them to Hell!
And now, let us teach our foes a lesson in good manners. We will politely slaughter them, and then give them a decent funeral!
And I promise you this: we will have work aplenty when the battle is done, gathering enemy heads and counting them.
And when this battle is done, let the smoke from the enemy funeral pyres block out the sun for many days!
And when we are done here, the sobs of their widows will rise to the heavens and even the Moon will weep in sympathy!
And now, remember that honour is at stake! If we lose our honour by fighting shamefully, that is too high a price for victory!
And now, let us go forward! Our names will live for a thousand years! Raise the banners!
And now, raise the banners, and cheer! Show the foe that we are coming, and that they should run, if they value their lives!
And now there is one thing more to do! We are ready, our banners are bright upon the breeze, and the day looks well for us!
And now, I pray that your ancestors will be proud of your efforts! You are dutiful sons of the clan. There is no finer boast!
And now comes the test that all wariors must face: open battle. Do not be afraid! You are under my command, and no man here is unworthy!
And now, I ask the spirits to keep our foes befuddled by their own foolishness. Our wits must be, will be, as sharp as our swords!
And now, as surely as Mount Fuji touches the clouds, we will have a victory! Good fortune to you all!
And now, to the enemy! It is impolite to keep them waiting for death any longer! I will enjoy counting their heads afterwards!
And now set aside all thoughts save duty. Your loved ones will mourn if you die, but not if you fail! Let us have victory!
And now, the hour has come to hurl ourselves into the enemy ranks and rip them to small pieces, fit only to be food for dogs!
And now, do not be still. Gut your enemies like fish, for they are not worthy of warrior deaths! Bring me heads! I will have heads today!
And now, I would see blood! I will have our banners dipped in the blood of many enemies before this day is done! That will mark our victory!
And now, we begin! Keep courage in your hearts, as I hold it in mine. With courage, there is no chance of failure!
And now, think on this: it is harder to live with cowardice in your heart than die with courage! So, be brave, my warriors!
And now have no fear of what is to come, for I do not! Set aside all thoughts of life until the battle is done! That way doubt will not trouble you!
And now, I refill my sake cup and raise it in your honour! You are fine fellows, and I admire and deeply love you all! Oh yes, much, much, more than I can say
And now I drink to your success. I have a flask or two that need my attention, you know. And try not to be too loud when you fight. Terribly bad for the digestion, too much noise
And now, I send you off to fight our foes, the horrible fish-faced devils with their scaly knees and goggly eyes. No, that's my wife's family! Anyway, good luck to you all!
And now, remember that the enemy are not blessed by fortune. They are men made of rice paper. Yes, rice paper. And chopsticks. Do not fear these spindly bamboo folk!
And now, I fear that I must attack the enemy with or without your help. It is the only way to stop them talking about me. Do not listen to them! I never loved that squid!
So, it has come to battle. I take comfort in knowing that the Moon People have a high regard for my dancing skills! Now we will dance with our swords, to a tune of victory!
And now I go to drown my sorrows in enemy blood! Any man who follows me must harden his heart, or prepare for madness, for I will not stop until victory is mine!
And now, I go to battle! I feel no shame to tell you that my face is wet with tears for those I have lost. Soon it will be wet with their damned blood!
And now, my heart tells me that it is time. It is time to draw my sword, and let madness take me. Follow, or stand aside, I care not! But if you want victory: follow!
And now, we are ready to do battle. I trust that all of you know your part, and that you will act with honour.
And now to battle! My honour can only be enhanced by leading you today, so do nothing that brings shame on our clan!
And so, put aside all thoughts of death. For us, there is only the honour of serving our clan, and the glory of victory!
At the last, I have nothing more to say. You know your duty, as I do mine. Our hearts are strong, so fight well!
And now, take up your arms, and realise that you are in the company of brave men. Anything, absolutely anything, is possible for such men!
And finally, I know that we are the best of our clan. As long as we have honour, even if we fall here we will not fail here!

And lastly I think back on the many battles I have fought, great and small. I think of the many comrades I have seen fall, and many I have seen crowned with victory. And I look around and see their equals! I look forward to victory in your company!
And now, I will say no more. You have had your fill of words. Now is the moment where my deeds must speak, and fill you with bravery for what is to come! Worthy warriors: come with me!

And remember: I did not achieve my position through weakness, or cowardice! No, I got here in the same way as you will win this battle: by being a warrior, obeying orders, understanding duty and maintaining honour! Any of you can do the same!
And finally, I have long worked for our clan's success. In peace and war, I have carried the iron weight of duty. Today is no different! If I fall, I die proud of commanding you!
And lastly, although I have honed my skills, they do not matter. All that matters now is that I command you with all my ability, and that you obey with all of yours. There is nothing more!

And now, I draw my sword, and add my voice to yours! Unless our enemies are ignorant men, they will know my name and my value! Both will cause them doubt and fear! One day, I trust, your names will do the same!
And remember that although I am not thought a warrior, my spirit has been forged in war. Battle is but poetry written in a splash of blood!
And now, remember that we are like the cherry blossom blowing on the wind. The winds of fate will be kind, as long the blossoms are worthy.
And now, remember that there is poetry in the sword's edge, and beauty in a noble death! Let us give our enemies many noble deaths!
And now, I have talked enough. It is time for us to fight, and for me to put my expertise to good use as your leader. I will not fail you, brave warriors!
And now, we go forwards towards victory! I promise that every thought of mine is devoted to the ruination of our foes! Do the same!
And so I finish my speech. I am not given to talking when I could be doing! Now is the time for great deeds!
And now, I say one thing more as a practical man and a warrior. Kill your foe when the order is given. There is nothing else to battle!
And at the last, I offer this practical advice to you all: stay alive and kill the enemy. That way, we will enjoy the victory together!
And now, my fellow warriors, look to your arms and armour one last time. Now cheer, and put fear in our enemies' guts!
And now, heroes: kill them all!
Let the heroes step forward, and show them death!
Draw your swords, heroes, and give them death!
And now, heroes of our clan, fight with honour!
Heroes! Show them what honour truly means!
And now, worthy heroes, your moment has come!
Now, prove yourselves worthy of our clan!
Now is the time! Do not dishonour the clan!
Take up your weapons, and do your worst!
Now, heroes, show our foes the meaning of duty!
Take your places in line! Fight well, my heroes!
Heroes of our clan! As always, fight bravely!
Now, heroes, send your foes to Hell!
Spirits! Grant our heroes a victory here!
Mighty heroes: my prayers go with you!
You have my prayers, brave heroes! Now fight!
Fight with honour, heroes of our clan!
Strike them down, heroes! We will have victory here!
Now, heroes of our people, advance with resolute hearts!
Fight! For your families and your honour!
And now, heroes, let duty guide your hearts!
Now, let glory and honour find champions among us!
Now, heroes, show you are worthy of that name!
Strength to you, heroes, as you face your challenges!
I pray for your victories, heroes!
This the moment for heroes to step forth and claim honour!
My prayers go with you as you seek honour today!
Seek out a worthy foe, and prove your courage!
Seek out a man worth fighting, and cut him down!
Spirits of the air! Cool the brows of these, my worthy heroes!
Mighty heroes! Destiny awaits you!
Mighty heroes! Let your deeds today live for ten thousand years!
Great heroes, I pray you find truly worth opponents!
Heroes of our clan! May you find glory and victory!
Live long in honour, worthy heroes! I wish you success!
I pray you find brave and noble foes, so that your honour is proved!
Heroes, this is your moment of glory, when all men can see your worth!
Fight well, noble heroes, for all our clan watches you!
Noble heroes, show your ancestors that you are worthy of them!
Your ancestors are watching, heroes! Make sure they are not ashamed!
And remember: your ancestors are watching! Do not shame them!
Now, let the crows feast!
The crows will feast on their flesh when we are done here!
The kami will expect bravery! Do not disappoint them!
And now: fight for the clan and your own honour!
And now let the spirits decide our fate, but fight hard!
The crows circle! Let us give them meat!
Let their dying screams terrify the wind and clouds!
Let the carrion beasts feed on our dead foes!
The crows are hungry! Let us make sure they are well fed!
Brave warriors, do not disappoint your ancestors today!
Now send them to unmarked, dishonoured graves!
Send them to Hell, my brave warriors!
And now let us fill a lake with orphans' tears!
Make ready! And act with honour today!
And think of this: honour does not seek out timid men!
And now draw your swords, and pray for victory!
Let every blow you give be honourable!
I pray that you fight with honour in your hearts!
And now, put aside all tender thoughts! Show no mercy!
Honour is worthy, but so too is victory!
Noble kami! Forgive us as we spill enemy blood on your lands!
Now, leave no man alive, my warriors!
If you should fall, make sure your wounds are to your front!
No quarter! No mercy! No weakness!
And now, courage! Our ancestors expect nothing else!
Courage, warriors, courage! Our clan's honour demands it!
Now, draw your sword! Take up your spear! Fight!
Do not fear your enemies. Their spirit is weak! To battle!
The spirits hate our enemies! What have we to fear, then?
And now, our foes must be trampled in the dirt!
Now, send them to Hell! No mercy!
Do not dance about like geisha! Fight!
Look to duty, honour and family. Now, fight!
And may demons drag their screeching souls to Hell!
Demons of Hell! I call on thee to smite our foes!
And now, look to your armour and your blades! Onwards!
Now send our enemies screaming down to Hell!
Do not fear them! Let them fear you! Now: cheer!
May our glory live for ten thousand years!
Now send them to the deeps!
Let the crabs feast on their flesh!
And I hope our foes do not poison the fish!
We will walk to shore on their floating corpses!
May the spirits drown them, and save us the trouble!
And I wish you all well of the day! Fight with courage!
And when we are done, the waves will wash away their stench!
Only the fish will remember them when we are done!
May they feed the fishes for a thousand years!
May the waves overwhelm and swallow them all!
May their sea-graves be forgotten by all!
I ask the wave-spirits bring them to despair and death!
Spirits of these waters: dash their ships to pieces!
Now, let us see them all drowned and dead!
To your posts, warriors! Send them to Hell!
Now, wave-spirits! Curse them, and bring them death!
And remember that even the wave-spirits hate them!
Now, let wind, wave and the deeps take their foul dead!
Nothing can now save the enemy from a watery death!
Now, let their flesh poison the crawling beasts of the seas!
And now, let the last thing they see be our victorious faces!
Their widows will wail, louder than any storm, when we are done!
For a thousand years, the crab spirits will give thanks for today's feast!
Warriors! Imitate the actions of the waves, and dash them to pieces!
And now, wave-spirits, claw at their hearts! Onwards, my warriors!
Gull-spirits, take the wind from their sails! Grant us easy victory!
Sailors! Do your duty! Warriors: do yours, and give us victory!
Let us cast them into the depths, with our curses weighing them down!
And now, let the gulls choke on their guts! To victory!
Do your duty as honest warriors! The waves will look after their dead!
Do not fear the spirits of the deep! They will overwhelm our foes!
And now: kill them! Let the sea take their flesh!
And now, pray for victory! The sea gods favour the brave!
The sharks await their feast! Let them dine on our foes!
Victory at sea is just as worthy as on land! Take heart! Fight well!
And now, we sail to victory!
Remember: your courage today will make a fine sea-tale!
Raise the battle flags! Harden your hearts! Now: fight!
I am honoured to lead such brave seafarers! Let us have victory!
And any man who drowns without permission answers to me! Ha!
Today we face the Ashikaga. If they had any sense, they would run, for their day is done. They are yesterday's warriors at best.
These loathesome Ashikaga should crawl into their graves now. They have no business interfering in the affairs of Japan.
Once, perhaps, the Ashikaga had a place in the affairs of state. Now, they should bow to the inevitable and slay themselves honourably.
Why do the Ashikaga not understand that their time is done? Are they so simple, so ignorant, that they cannot see the way of the world?
Now we must fight the Ashikaga! They are men of little worth, and less prowess. If they had any talent, they would serve a different master!
These Ashikaga are even greater fools than I was told! Why do they waste their honour in so stupid a cause? Why defend the indefensible?
Why will these Ashikaga fools simply not take their own lives rather than fight? That way, at least, they could claw back some honour from their deeds!
The old days are gone! The new days are beginning! The Ashikaga are ghosts, no more than the echoes of a once-worthy clan! They should welcome death!
I had heard that our Ashikaga enemies were cultured people with most excellent manners. So why have they not committed suicide? Why do they fight?
Our enemies, the Ashikaga, are proud of their lineage! They are proud of ruining Japan, of insulting the Emperor, of being entirely useless. What fools!
Today we face a worthy clan, but one whose time is over. The Ashikaga would do better to commit suicide, and retain some honour.
The Ashikaga yonder have come to reclaim their honour, and once it was great. This misguided quest of theirs will cost them dear at our hands.
I pity these Ashikaga warriors! Once they were great men, and served a great cause. Now, they are reduced to sword-fodder and practice targets!
Over there the Ashikaga await our pleasure. They are brave, but they fight for a cause which does not deserve their bravery. Their deaths are regretable.
I salute our Ashikaga foes! Their dedication to their lost cause is most admirable, and utterly futile! It is a sadness that many will die for it!
I salute the Ashikaga! They are notable for their skills in war, and their honour as men. I am saddened that we must be enemies.
The Ashikaga think they are doing the right thing, I do not doubt that for a moment! Instead, they only prolong Japan's suffering by resisting!
The Ashikaga are an old, proud clan! They have earned the right to be proud, but their defiance is vexing and inconvenient!
The Ashikaga have good cause to be proud. They are an honourable folk, and my heart is heavy that we will shortly kill so many worthy men.
We face the Ashikaga. For many years, they have stood watch over the Emperor and the Shogun. Now, however, it is their time to step aside!
The Chosokabe over there are simple people. They are like an arrow: when ordered, they fly towards their foes until they fall insensible to the ground. Idiots!
One day, perhaps, the Chosokabe will understand their place in the affairs of Japan. One day, perhaps, my horse will learn to write haiku!
I see a kind stranger has guided the Chosokabe here! This is good, for they might have got lost otherwise! A battle needs both sides!
Those Chosokabe are like rotten wood used for a bow: they look acceptable, but beneath the lacquer their foul hearts are eaten away!
We face an unpleasant foe. The Chosokabe were once accounted masters of the bow. Now they are masters only of deceit, cruelty and greed.
Do not think of your Chosokabe as men. They are not: geisha have more courage, and gravediggers better manners! It will be pleasing to break them!
Our Chosokabe enemies are master archers, by some accounts. Good! I would not want to fight with them too closely, because they are unwashed and offensive!
If there is a single Chosokabe warrior who has manners, or who understands how to behave well, I have yet to see him. He does not exist!
These Chosokabe test my patience! Why will they not recognise that we are the better men? They are reputed to shoot well enough, but so what?
When we are finished, I want Chosokabe widows and sisters to weep. This is not as cruel as it sounds, for they are often the same women!
We must watch our foes carefully. The Chosokabe are like an arrow: direct and quite, quite deadly. Once released, they will be fierce!
The Chosokabe are honest foes, and do not indulge themselves in complicated stratagems. What we see before us is what we must kill.
I see the Chosokabe are now arrayed for battle. They are an honourable clan, and we must strike them down with equal honour.
The Chosokabe await our pleasure. Even rivals admit they are dangerous bowmen, yet this is also a weakness, making them neglectful of other things.
Bishamon has blessed the Chosokabe with war skills and courage! This is to be welcomed! If we faced weaklings, how would we measure our worth?
These Chosokabe are fine bowmen, especially by their own account! Ha! But what are they like when the targets fight back? We shall see!
The Chosokabe look proud, standing beneath their banners, in their fine armour, with their fine weapons. I hope they can fight, as well as look the part!
We have come to fight the Chosokabe, an enemy we should respect. They are fine warriors, skilled in the bow and not without cunning.
We face the Chosokabe. This is good, for easy victories bring little credit to the victors. An honourable opponent should be welcomed, and then slain!
Over there, the Chosokabe general speaks to his men. I will echo what I trust he is saying: today we face honourable foes, and should respect them!
Over there, the Date are waiting to kill us, because they are a barbarous clan, and foolish. We are not to be slaughtered for their entertainment.
The Date await our pleasure! Well, I mean to make them wait for a moment longer! Let fear work its magic on their reputedly fearsome bowels!
I do not care for those Date banners! I find their colour offensive, and the clan they stand for ill-mannered, unwashed, odious and crass!
These Date try my patience and my temper. They are a needlessly cruel clan, given to oppressing those they conquer. They have a taste for bloodshed!
Over there, the Date are getting ready. Many of them will die today but few will mourn them. Their mistreated wives may even be grateful to us!
I curse the name of "Date" and all who serve in their armies. They are demons, not men, given to vice and degradation. Bah!
I would give thanks for ten thousand years if Raiden sent a storm to wash the Date away! Their wickedness pollutes our nation!
We are here to face cruelty in human form! We are here to confront the Date, who are despised by all honest and just men!
Bishamon give us strength, for we fight the Date! They are fierce warriors, skilled and without scruples. Do not expect honourable conduct from them!
Over there, the Date general is denouncing you as dishonourable, weak, womanly and worse! His is an ill-mannered clan, and they deserve death!
The Date are rightly regarded as fierce people. They are unforgiving, relentless even, and these qualities are their weakness: they are foolhardy when thwarted!
The Date have little poetry in their souls. They are men of battle, and this is a weakness: they see little point in anything beyond the sword.
Our Date foes are considered a cruel and fierce people. Nonsense! They are direct, honest, simple warriors! They recognise cruelty is only a tool of rulership!
Our Date enemies have many fine qualities. They are unforgiving in war, and fierce towards others. This can blind them in battle. It is a weakness.
Bishamon be praised! We have a foe worthy of our swords! These Date are a fierce and warlike folk, and will die well at our hands!
These Date are a dangerous and skilled enemy. I am most gratified to face them, for when we win no one will dare deny our honour!
These Date breed fierce warriors: men with the spirit of a tiger. The men who beat such a foe will surely gain fame and honour!
I am sure that the Date are already congratulating themselves for their victory here! I like their confidence! But it is misplaced, because they face you!
Over there, the Date general is telling his men about the magnificent enemy they face! Good, let him praise us, for there is fear in his words!
Is there any sight finer than this? We have a noble enemy, the Date, and they make a fine show! It seems wrong to spoil such perfection!
Our foes, the Hattori, are cunning beasts! Mother foxes send their cubs to learn their vicious tricks from the Hattori. I do not like them.
There are no creatures more treacherous than the Hattori! I would spurn them with my foot, but they would steal my sock as I did it!
These Hattori devils make common cause with ninjas, bandits, robbers, brigands and all manner of dishonoured swines. I am sorry we must fight them.
I have never heard any man say anything good about the Hattori, unless he had a Hattori knife at his throat. They deserve death!
One day, perhaps, the gods will strike down the Hattori. Until that day, the job of culling these foxes lies with men like us!
Over there the Hattori are already celebrating their victory. They hold all other clans in contempt. Still, fools die as easily as wise men.
I do not like these Hattori at all. They are too fond of the shadows, of murder, and of foul lies to be thought honest warriors.
Over their the Hattori banners are flying! Each one is a sign of dishonour, and of murderous treachery. They show brazen gall in daring to face us!
Yonder you can see the lying, cruel and false soldiers of a Hattori army. Every one of them is dishonoured, simply by where he stands. Bah!
Over there, beneath that ugly rag they call a banner, is a Hattori general. Even now, he is lying to his men and telling them you are weak: chickens to their foxes.
Our foes, the Hattori, are now gathered! They are cunning warriors, so always bear in mind that you cannot always see a Hattori until he strikes!
Over there is a Hattori army, at least what we can see of it! Remember that they are masters of cunning, so expect the unexpected!
Over there, I am sure, the Hattori general is being honest with this men, telling them about their dangerous foes. Do not make him a liar!
Our foes, the Hattori, are dangerous warriors. Some call them sneaky, fox-cunning and false: all that is true, but then it should be true of all warriors!
I do not expect our Hattori opponents to fight fairly today. I expect them to use trickery and falsehood. Knowing this, we are prepared!
The Hattori are masters of trickery in battle. We should respect them for this, for only a foolish general lays aside a weapon.
It seems wrong, somehow, to wish destruction on such a handsomely arrayed force as the Hattori. But we must destroy them, for they oppose us!
I am sure that you have all seen the Hattori banners yonder. They make a brave show, but we would do well to remember the Hattori we cannot see!
The Hattori have a proud tradition of warfare. Therefore, it is good to face them, for how much greater the honour in beating such men?
The Hattori are fierce, cruel, and treacherous. These strengths are also weaknesses, for what kind of fool would stick his hand into the fox's jaws?
Our foes, the cursed Hojo, hold themselves better than other men. And for what reason? Their castles? They know how to stack stones? So do mewling infants!
Over there, under their scruffy flags, the Hojo await. Their general speaks to them of their bravery. Oh, he must be a great liar!
I see our Hojo foes have now gathered themselves into some sort of order! It must be very depressing to be their commander.
Over there stand the Hojo. They are like a house, built on river mud. You cannot trust them to stand before a flood such as us!
Our Hojo foes are most excellent builders. They have something in common with their fortresses: they are about as intelligent as stones!
These Hojo are most comfortable behind strong walls. This is not a sound attitude for a warrior people. Honour requires open, honest battle!
The Hojo are accounted fine builders by some, as if manual labour was a matter of pride in warriors! Bah! They are lowly diggers and labourers!
The Hojo are not honest samurai! They are less than ronin! They are peasants, labouring in the dirt and pretending to martial glory! Bah!
These Hojo think very highly of themselves. Even their banners have an insolence that tests my patience! I thank Bishamon that we are fighting them!
At this moment, the Hojo warriors are being told that you are common, unwashed peasants. Their general is lying to them, trying to instil false courage!
Our Hojo enemies make a proud display, and with some justification. Their clan is worthy of respect, although their reasons for being here require their defeat!
The Hojo over there are brave men. Their clan is famed for its skills and its learning. Today, I hope they will learn one thing: to fear us!
Our Hojo enemies are now prepared. We will make this an honest fight, and destroy them in open battle. They are worthy of the honour!
Our Hojo foes are most excellent builders. It is good that men have a trade: it can support them when warrior pretensions are swept away.
Some think the Hojo are little better than stone-masons and labourers. This is foolishness! They build castles, it is true, but then they fight like demons!
The Hojo are an honourable clan! Their strategies in warfare are often cunning and imaginative! We would do well not to underestimate them!
There are calculations in warfare that every general makes: here, I consider the Hojo to be a dangerous foe! We will engage them with caution!
Do not make the mistake of dismissing the Hojo as cowards or fools. They are neither, and their generals are cunning men too.
Do not treat our Hojo enemies with disrespect! I want them defeated, but we will do it and maintain our honour! Courtesy is not weakness!
The Hojo yonder are easy to underestimate! It is tempting to think of them as nothing more than builders of castles, but this is wrong. They are warriors!
The Mori like to think that they are masters of the sea, lords of the ocean. In fact, they are slightly less valuable than crabs, washed up by a winter storm!
Over there our foes are waiting. They are waiting, as the Mori always do, to rob and loot, for at heart they are thieves not warriors!
I am surprised that the Mori have managed to gather so many fighters. Perhaps they were expecting boundless sake and numberless whores!
I assume so many Mori have come because they have been promised loot! Usually, it is the only thing that makes them leave their drinking dens!
The Mori call themselves the lords of the sea. To lesser men, this sounds impressive, I admit. They claim lordship over fish. Hhhhhmmmmmm.
The Mori are sea-creatures, every one! Perhaps, like other fish, they need to be gutted before they are acceptable at dinner! Shall we be about them?
These Mori are hateful, piratical beasts! Would that Ebisu had drowned them all in a seastorm! But he has not, so we must execute them!
When we are done with these Mori fools, Ebisu will give thanks to us, I trust! His fishermen will be a little safer from pirates!
These Mori are not men, merely sharks! They are cruel, greedy and insatiable. My humble apologies, but there is little honour in killing them!
Even the crabs, crawling on the bottom of the sea, have heard of the Mori and dislike them. And crabs make infinitely better eating!
The Mori call themselves the lords of the sea. They are fine seamasters, but are they fine fighters? I do not think it so!
Some call the Mori pirates, some call them thieves. This dismisses them too easily. They are dangerous people, and should be respected.
Although the Mori are, given the chance, pirates and sea-thieves, they are also cunning fighters. They have a certain bravery, so be careful!
Our swords may be soaked in Mori blood when we are done, but our enemies are worthy of the honour of dying at our hands!
Ebisu himself must favour the Mori! What other god would bother protecting them? Try not to offend him, even as you kill the Mori!
Ah! These Mori are cunning fighters, at home on land and sea. How much greater is our honour when we beat them in an honest fight?
I do not like the Mori, but I respect their skills! I suggest you do the same, unless you want to be lacking a head!
To many, the Mori are a clan of pirates, thieves, ruffians, brigands and worse. Do not think of them in that way. They have honour, of a kind.
The Mori yonder make a brave sight! But that does not mean we should do anything other than defeat them. They are the lesser men here!
We are here to fight the Mori! They are a brave clan, masters of the seas, and skilled in strategy. We must show proper respect!
The Oda over there put much faith in their common troopers, and in their generalship. Today we shall show that faith is sadly misplaced!
The Oda like to think that they are the consumate warriors, unmatched by any lesser men. Their stupidity in thinking this is certainly unique!
These are the Oda. I think they are the stupidest creatures the Gods put on earth. The Oda might disagree if anyone could explain this to them.
The Seven Lucky Gods be thanked! Here is a foe worth hating! These Oda are not fit to dig latrines, let alone call themselves soldiers!
There is a darkness in the hearts of the Oda clan. They are not truly honourable men: they love victory for its own sake. We must best them.
The Oda are tricksters. If they move right, expect an attack to the left! Nothing is as it seems with them, for they are dishonest to the bone!
Do not consider the Oda strong! They are weaklings, reliant on commanders who browbeat their men and allow no individual to show proper courage!
I do not like those Oda banners! The men who hold them high should die of shame! They are the flags of dishonour!
These Oda warriors have a most peculiar smell to them! I do not believe they are cultured men, but peasants dragged from a dungheap!
I give thanks to Bishamon that we have a foe who needs killing! Some men are unlucky in their clan, but these Oda fools relish their wicked ill-luck!
The Oda, it is said, have common soldiers the equal of any in Japan. This may be true, but they have yet to be measured against you!
The Oda over there are a disciplined and skilled army. They should never be underestimated. That said, they are also quite mortal, and bleed well!
Over there the Oda are waiting. They are not to be underestimated, for they produce fearsome armies. This will be a battle worth recounting!
It is a foolish general who underestimates the power of the Oda clan! In war they are disciplined and clever! We will treat them with caution!
These Oda warriors carry themselves well! It would be foolish indeed to dismiss them as slaves to their daimyo. They have strong spirits!
My heart is heavy! Those Oda soldiers do not deserve death at our hands. They are unfortunate indeed to serve that clan!
The Oda are serious men, and well versed in the ways of war. We owe it to them to be serious in our attitudes to this battle!
Bishamon give us strength! We will need it against these Oda soldiers! They are a mighty host, made mightier by their warlike ways!
My soul is saddened, that we must now kill so many fine warriors. The Oda clan bear a heavy burden of guilt for killing so many to so little purpose!
These Oda are mighty warriors indeed. Any student of strategy would look at their ranks and see strength and resolution! I, however, see dead men!
The Shimazu yonder think themselves better than other men, that their bloodline is more than ours. I say they are wrong! And we will prove it!
The Shimazu account themselves noble, better than lesser men. I think they are misguided; that dung wrapped in a silk kimono is still dung!
The Shimazu are no better than grave-robbers, stealing glory from their long-dead ancestors. Once they were noble, but now? Bah!
Our Shimazu enemies have a high opinion of themselves, and their ancestors. It must irk them constantly that everyone else thinks differently!
Let us consider our Shimazu foes for a moment. They are a sorry collection of ne'er-do-wells and ruffians, the worthless heirs to a worthless clan!
Over there the Shimazu are waiting. They are long bred to evil and corruption, for that is their heritage. Their banners are marks of dishonour!
These Shimazu spoil what would otherwise be a pleasing view. Despite their pretensions, they lack any appreciation of beauty. They deserve death a thousand times over.
Over there, the Shimazu general is reminding his men of their lineage: a long tale of thievery and deceit, of which he will say nothing. Bah!
The Shimazu have a long history. It is a history befouled by tales of friends betrayed, women violated, and unspeakable sin! And we face them today!
If there is a Shimazu fool over there more noble than the pigs in a peasant's hut, I will eat my helmet, crest and all!
The Shimazu over there have a proud lineage. Their ancestors were mighty men. How they must weep to see their sons' folly today.
Over there the Shimazu banners fly proudly, as well they might. They were once carried by mighty men. Today, their sons are somewhat lesser creatures.
Our Shimazu foes are the heirs to a noble tradition of service and duty. I am sure that they will acquit themselves with honour as they die!
Over there the Shimazu await us. They are an ancient clan, well founded in honour and skilled in war. This will be worthy of a tale or two!
By the Seven Lucky Gods, I count myself fortunate to face the Shimazu, a noble clan indeed. How much sweeter is victory over such an enemy?
The Shimazu clan have fought many wars. They are experienced in strategy, and this makes them dangerous. We shall fight them with prudence!
These Shimazu descend from mighty ancestors. I hope, though, that their blood is not that of yesterday, but of an altogether weaker degree!
I weep at the slaughter we must now do! These Shimazu are the proud children of a great clan but, like children, they have been led astray!
These Shimazu have been forged in war, like a sword in the furnace! We must take care, lest they cut us to the bone!
I am moved to see the Shimazu warriors yonder. It is their part to die here, if I have my way. But I do not like killing worthy men.
I smell the reek of stables, so here we must be fighting the Takeda! I think they take their love of horses just a little too far!
The Takeda think themselves better than others, although I cannot understand why! Living in a stables does not confer nobility on ordinary men!
I could never decide who commanded in a Takeda army. Then I realised it did not matter! When everyone is an idiot, why have any leadership?
I can hazard a guess that the Takeda general is, right now, telling his men that they are clever and brave. They, being stupid, believe every word!
Over there the Takeda are waiting for us. They are not to be trusted: men bred in mountains count brigands and worse among their ancestors!
I see the Takeda have hoisted their horse blankets to use as foul-smelling banners for their flea-bitten army. Bah! One day, perhaps they will wash!
I would pray to Fjin to send a breeze to keep the Takeda stench from us, but I fear that even the gods cannot help!
The Takeda have come down from their mountains and out of their dungheaps, then! We do Japan a service by slaying them!
By the Seven Lucky Gods, why are the Takeda here? Have these mountain monkeys no shame? Surely they see they are entirely foolish to face us?
Here we fight the odious Takeda! I swear by my sword that I shall not rest while one of them remains alive! They pollute this place!
The Takeda over there are famed as horse-masters, and rightly so. Being able to ride, however, does not makes them unbeatable. This we will prove.
There is much to admire in the Takeda clan! Their mountains breed fierce men and fierce loyalties. Yet, measured against you, they are still wanting!
Over there, the Takeda warriors wait for you. Do not think they are unworthy, or cowards, or fools because they march beneath a different banner.
The Takeda clan are not fools! Their soldiers are tough and resourceful, and their generals are cultured and clever. Caution should be our watchword!
These Takeda are resourceful and hardy men, bred in their mountains from generations of warriors. We would do well to respect their strength!
Even as I speak to you, our Takeda foes are listening to their general. He is telling them they are fine warriors. I agree, but they need killing!
See: the Takeda have raised their banners! They are a proud clan, and with good reason. It will be a pleasure to defeat such men!
Now, look to your enemies, the Takeda! Mark them well, and understand that each of them is a righteous man. We will kill them with decorum!
I am saddened to fight the Takeda! They would be worthy allies in our cause, if only their leaders had the wit to see it!
Sometimes the gods must weep to see great men fight and die uselessly. The gods will weep today for the Takeda dead when we are done!
The Tokugawa are masters of falsehood and lies. They call themselves "diplomats", but their nice manners are the mask of evil! I know of what I speak!
The only word from a lying Tokugawa throat that we expect to hear is "Mercy!" The only correct response from you is the sword!
Over there, the Tokugawa are wishing that they were whoring and drinking rather than waiting for battle. They are not, at heart, honest warriors!
Even now, the Tokugawa general is praising his men! He thinks he need do nothing but fill them with words and the battle is won! What a fool!
I do not care for those Tokugawa banners. They are lacking in many respects, but chiefly I am offended by the men holding them!
The Tokugawa yonder are great talkers. Unfortunately, their fine words are likely to be a little muffled today because their arses are encased in armour!
Over there, the Tokugawa general is telling his men that you are demons, women, and dishonoured weaklings. But remember: he is a talker, not a fighter!
The Tokugawa like to talk while they plunge a knife into an man's guts! They are not honourable! Remember that as you face them!
The Tokugawa are not warriors! They are old women, full of years and gossip! Do not fear them! Instead, pity them as you collect their heads!
I cannot bring myself to trust the Tokugawa! I respect them, of course: it is prudent to respect the snake and its venom!
The Tokugawa we face here are great talkers. They could talk the blossom off cherry trees! We shall see how their words fare against our swords!
When we are done, I want the Tokugawa to talk of this day for a hundred years! We must leave one alive to tell of our deeds!
I am sure that the Tokugawa general is giving his troops a rousing speech, as is his duty. Let him! They are gossips! We are fighters!
The Tokugawa yonder have done well for themselves: they have clawed their way out of obscurity. Therefore, be wary of them in battle!
Do not despise our foes! The Tokugawa cannot boast mighty ancestors, as some clans do. But they can boast cunning warriors today!
There is much honour to be gained in fighting an honourable foe. These Tokugawa soldiers understand honour, and what it means! This is most satisfactory!
The Tokugawa banners are a noble sight! Beneath them, their warriors are honourable and worthy opponents. We are blessed by Bishamon to face such men!
There is much to admire about the Tokugawa clan. But we must not let admiration blind us to their most important fault: they are our enemies!
I am saddened that we must fight the Tokugawa. Men of such quality should be our allies, but fate has decreed otherwise. Let us behave honourably, then!
We must cast down those Tokugawa banners! The men who will defend them are honourable, and deserve honourable deaths at our hands!
I see our Uesugi foes waste time before the fight by bleating prayers to the uncaring sky. Do they not know they are hated in heaven and on earth?
So then, we shall allow our esteemed Uesugi foes a moment to pray. Even if we gave them a hundred years, their sins would still weigh them down!
Over there, the Uesugi commander is callling on Heaven to aid his cause. I hope Raiden is listening! A thunderclap into his skull would be just!
I wish that Fjin would blow the Uesugi back to their foul nest! Answer that prayer, gods, and my gratitude will last a lifetime!
Bishamon protect us from pious men! Or better still, from the false, preening piety of the Uesugi. The sword's edge will punctuate their godly muttering!
Those Uesugi banners are spoiling my view. You may not think that important but, for me, they disturb the beauty of the clouds. I want them down!
How the gods must be bored by the wailing of the Uesugi! Even now, they will be grovelling away, asking for help! Bah!
I despise our Uesugi foes, not because they are poor fighters, but because they constantly proclaim their piety! It is false pride, dressed in religious robes!
Gods! Do not listen to the Uesugi fools we face! Their piety is a mask, covering up their corrupt and dishonoured hearts! Support us instead!
The Uesugi yonder think themselves pious and godly. Perhaps, perhaps, but they are also unprincipled, vicious and deceitful in war! Be wary of them!
Our foes are pious men. We should give the Uesugi enough time for prayer and contemplation. When they are done, we will kill them.
The Uesugi banners make a proud display, and the clan has some claim to virtue. I think, though, that in opposing us they confuse wisdom with folly.
I trust that the Uesugi over there are being polite and praying for our souls. It would be a respectful act, and they are honourable men.
By Bishamon, I do believe our Uesugi enemies are praying for our souls! That is most polite of them, but a wasted effort. Today, they die!
I think Bishamon must look down on the Uesugi yonder with some pride. They are a fine sight! When we are done, matters will be otherwise!
I see the Uesugi banners make a brave sight, thanks to the winds of Fjin. Appearance, however, is not reality! The Uesugi can pray, but we can fight!
Over there, the Uesugi general offers up prayers for his success and our souls! If I have any say in this battle, his prayers will not be answered!
Men, we must give the Uesugi enough time to prepare their souls for the afterlife! They are honourable, and deserve that much from us!
Other than prayer, there is little the Uesugi can do here. Let them ask heaven for aid! We, on the other hand, will fight like demons from Hell!
The Uesugi yonder are honourable people, but their prayers for aid must weary the gods! Can these men not stand up for themselves?
Our foes have many faults, but the worst is believing that they are fit to face us. What are they? Peasants who yesterday washed for the first time!
I despise our foes! They meddle in affairs that are far above them. It is as if gravediggers, or worse, dared to debate a lord's policies!
Only pigs and peasants would bother to salute our enemies. They are little better than either. They pretend to understand honour. They need killing.
I am infuriated by the presumption and nave arrogance of our enemies! How dare they stand against us? By what right do they meddle in our affairs?
You may ask "Who are our enemies?" but I choose not to recognise their banners. They are the dead, awaiting the grave, that is all.
Our enemies are hardly a sight to inspire or terrify a man! Ha! I did not know all midden dwellers belonged to the same clan!
Our foes today are dishonoured and dishonourable. They were born in filth, and will die unloved, their infamy a shroud to wrap their rotting corpses.
Those fools weary me, and we have not even fought! Foolishness is always tiring, and when it is combined with immense and pointless arrogance - bah!
Those creatures over there are the puppets of a vicious, unprincipled and duplicitous man! Their daimyo thinks himself far, far better than he is!
I hate those men, for their presumption and their overweening arrogance! How dare they face us? They should be on their knees, begging for their lives!
Our foes are not yet important in the affairs of Japan. But do not let this fool you: they are dangerous opponents and may yet prove significant.
I salute our foes! They are warriors of a lesser clan, yet they show greatness in their hearts by facing us! They need killing!
Our foes fly their banners proudly. They have done much in raising up their clan, and deserve their pride. They also deserve death for coming here!
Our foes, then, are men of a lesser clan. You might think them unworthy because of it, and you would be wrong! They are warriors!
Even as I speak, our enemies await! They are not of a mighty clan, and they do well not to run from us!
Our foes are loyal and brave to their clan and master. I feel a sadness that we must destroy them, but such is the decree of fate!
Spirits of this place! I apologise for what is to happen! But blame the bravery of our enemies: if they ran away, you would not be offended!
Our enemies are warriors of a lesser clan: they are brave and worthy foes, even if their ambition is too great for their station in life!
These warriors impress me, a little. Perhaps, in time, their clan might become great and be accounted important. They will never know, for we will kill them.
It is a sad day when we must cut down the men yonder. Their only errors are to be in the wrong place and to serve the wrong master.
I am not impressed with these foreigners. They dare to think themselves equal to us, the finest warriors of Japan. Ha! Such presumption merits death!
I dislike our enemies! They pretend to be virtuous warriors and to understand duty. Yet all I see from them is falsehood and lies!
Our enemies think themselves our equals! That is why they dare to oppose us! In this, they must be fools, for they are not Japanese!
Is there any point in taking our foes' heads? They are so irredeemably ugly that they will surely turn my stomach, and so spoil our victory!
These foreigners will not fight as we do! They are soft-hearted and womanly, and given to wailing and begging for mercy. Show them none!
It is wrong for foreigners to attack Japanese lands, that much is obvious. Yet, in their folly, our foes have demonstrated some warrior virtues!
I salute our foes! They are not Japanese, yet they show the same courage and sense of duty I would expect from any of you!
Our foes are foreign, but do not think less of them because of their unfortunate origins! They are brave men, and deserve respect and caution!
Even as you kill them, remember that our enemies are worthy men, and brave enough to be Japanese! Do not treat them with contempt!
Our foes are not Japanese, but they are still notable enemies! I salute them for their courage, even as I wish to see them utterly destroyed!
The foreigners we face today have a most peculiar smell to them. I do not believe they ever wash. I am not sure they are actually human.
These fools we face have come from the far side of the world. It must be a poor place, to produce such foul-smelling creatures.
It is beyond my understanding why these foul beasts come to Japan, other than for rape, pillage and loot. They have no honour beyond the ocean!
Why do these half-men dare to oppose us? Why do they not scuttle back to the rats' nest that gave them birth? They are without shame!
I am sorry, noble warriors, for bringing you here. Our enemies are the flotsam of the world, washed up like dead fish on our beautiful shores.
These foreigners show some courage. They have come from the far side of the world, knowing nothing, but they still face death with dignity.
Our foes are alien, other, from beyond the sea. They do not respect our ways. But they have courage aplenty, to come here and face us.
Our foes are strange, it is true, but they are honourable after their own fashion. They stand with their brothers, and await death with dignity.
These foreigners from the far side of the world: they seen much that would frighten lesser men. That does not give them the right to oppose us!
I cannot find it in my heart to hate our enemies. They are brave men, although not Japanese. But I will not allow them to oppose us!
I do not care for our foes. Their sanctimonious ways and false superiority annoy me beyond all reason. I will be happier when they are dead.
To be faithful does not excuse rebellion! Nothing excuses revolt against the natural order of the world! Our foes, therefore, should be hated!
Our foes have masked their rebellion, their ingratitude to their masters, with the false face of piety! They are treacherous, to lie in such a manner!
Those rebels claim their faith is enough reason for their rebellion. There is never enough reason for rebellion! They are faithless to their masters!
I despise our enemies! They talk of faith, and duty, and enlightenment, but all the time their hearts are full of anger and resentment.
Our enemies today have a powerful faith to sustain them. I trust it will be a comfort as they die!
The faithful are over there. They should feel nothing but pride in their beliefs, and nothing but shame in their rebellious ways!
There is much to be said in defence of religious belief! Faith gives a man great purpose, but not when harnessed to the wrong cause.
Our Buddhist foes are honourable men in many ways, save one: they have abandoned obedience and duty! Rebellion, no matter what its banner, is rebellion!
Our foes are men of deep faith, and for this I respect them. But when that becomes the arrogance of rebellion I can tolerate them no longer!
Our foes are fools, led astray by foreign liars. They welcome death because they think it is the way to eternal life. They are madmen.
The fools over there have been seduced into the worship of a foreign god. It has driven them insane! Their death cult is repugnant and unnatural!
Our Christian foes have been driven mad by foreign devils! We should not pity them! We should burn out the infection of their madness!
To be a warrior is to accept death! But these Christians are in love with death, even when it is a useless end to life!
Why have so many fools followed this cult of the dead? What good can a dead god do them? I do not understand stupidity!
Our foes have many faults, but they are honest in their faith. Do not kill them because they are Christian. Kill them because they are enemies.
Do not be disturbed by any strange singing or chanting by our foes. They are Christians, and quite mad. We do Japan a service by fighting them.
Our Christian foes are strange, in many ways. When we kill them, they claim a victory through martyrdom. It is both futile and admirable.
This Christian faith has attracted many brave men to its banners. Their honour is not lessened by their beliefs. We must now, however, shorten their lives!
It is one thing to honourably believe in a new god. It is quite another to rebel against your masters. For the second, we are the punishment!
Our loathsome foes are peasants, no better than the farmyard beasts they sleep with. They should have stayed in their mud huts.
Spirits of the air! Keep the stench of our foes away from me! Surely even these peasants could have washed before they came here to die!
To judge by the smell, we face an army of dung-loving creatures: rats, perhaps, not men. Kill them swiftly, and do not let them bite you!
These peasants are unnatural folk! Would they have the whole world destroyed by earthquakes and floods? They must be taught their place! By the sword!
Those peasant rebels should not face soldiers, like you, but executioners! I am sorry for the duty I must now ask of you: simple slaughter!
Our foes may be peasants, but do not despise them for their lowly origins. Any man can show a warrior's courage.
Those peasants have some courage! It takes bravery to watch your family starve and to leave your lands to fight! Now we will let them die bravely!
Without peasants, we would all starve! They are the foundations of all! But foundations need to stay beneath a building, not try to topple it!
There is no glory to be found in the rice fields, only backbreaking hardship. The only escape we can offer them is death!
To be a peasant is to live in despair. Each seeks an escape from their drudgery. All we can offer today is a clean death!
Our foes are men without honour, ronin who should have chosen suicide rather than rebellion. When we are done, they will be glad of death!
The fate of a ronin is hard: with a master, without a clan, without hope! But these men have gone further: they are without honour!
To lose your master may be unfair and cruel. But it does not excuse taking up arms in this fashion! These ronin have forfeited everything, including their lives!
Our enemies were once men of honour, but not now! They have forfeited duty and soon, thanks to you, they will forfeit their worthless, wasted lives!
I despise these ronin! Why could they not retain honour when they lost their rightful masters? The way of the warrior is the acceptance of death!
Our foes are ronin, men without a clan. But do not think of them as men without honour! They are worthy men, and cunning fighters.
Even as we kill our foes, we should respect them. It is not an easy thing to be ronin, and to have lost all status.
Would that our ronin foes had a master to guide them. Their lives are thrown away, in a struggle that can bring them nothing but sorrow.
It is not an easy thing to lose a master, to find yourself adrift in the uncaring world. Pity your foe, then, even as you cut him down.
Once these ronin were honourable men, with lords and lands of their own. Now they follow another path, a misguided path. It is our part to block that path!
Men of the Chosokabe! We are ready! Like the arrow, ready to fly and released, we hurl ourselves into any fray!
Stand tall, you brave Chosokabe! Let the enemy see that you are mighty men, fearsome and resolute. Fear, like an arrow, pierces them now!
We Choskabe are plain, honest men. Our lives as warriors are measured in battles won and women kissed! Both measures will increase today!
I speak to you as one warrior to his brothers. We Chosokabe fight here because we must. All fault is on the side of our enemies.
Before he releases his shot, the bowman empties his thoughts. He waits, and at the perfect moment, the arrow flies. We are an arrow, released by our daimyo!
Brave Chosokabe! Loyal Chosokabe! What more need be said of you? Nothing! You are the best of our clan!
This is a good day! Now, my warriors, is the day we prove Chosokabe honour! Now is the day when Chosokabe glory is increased!
I am a plain-speaking Chosokabe general! So: I say to you that we are the better men here, and serve an honest cause! We are Chosokabe!
Chosokabe! Chosokabe! Chosokabe! There is no prouder boast for a warrior! Our wives and sweethearts will weep with joy when they hear of our bravery!
Let widows wail for a thousand lonely nights when they hear the name of Chosokabe! Let us be the arrow of grief that pierces a thousand hearts!
Date warriors! Your fierce reputation goes before you! Your enemies shiver inside their armour. Do not prolong their fear: give them the comfort of death!
Raise our banners, you Date warriors! Let the enemy see them! Let them see who has come to teach them respect and fear in equal measure!
We Date are a fierce people, unforgiving in war, implacable in battle, immovable in defence! Here, now, we will show our foes all this is true!
Now we must prepare for battle! Put aside all tender thoughts of family and home! Raise our Date banners! Let them see we are here!
Make ready, brave Date warriors! Already our foes are wary, for they think us savage and cruel! We are not, but I thank their weak gullibility!
Date Warriors! When we are done today, I want horror to fill the souls of any who hear of our deeds! Fear is also a weapon!
And now, mighty warriors, we are to do battle! We Date are called cruel, and we may be, but we are also brave, steadfast and loyal!
Here I stand, Date warriors! Here, if necessary, I will die! But if I die it will be in triumph, fighting for our clan and its honour!
Brave Date! We are the defenders of our clan, its strong right arm, its sword to cut down foes! Stand proudly beneath our banners!
We Date are considered fierce by our enemies! Good! If they fear us, then a battle is won before the first blow is struck!
We Hattori have an unfortunate reputation for deceit, cruelty and war-making! Excellent! This means our name is already a sword-cut into the enemies' bellies!
Hattori warriors! After our today, those who hear of our deeds here should shudder with terror! We must be demons of battle, not men!
Now, brave Hattori, stand proudly beneath our banners! Let the enemy see you, and let them fear! Their hearts weaken, and they are already lost!
I will not keep you long, my brave Hattori warriors! All is ready, and you need no encouragement from me to fight like proper men!
We Hattori are hardy, resourceful and clever! We have to be, for our mountain home is harsh and unforgiving! We know the world is against us!
Raise high our banners, my Hattori warriors! Let the enemy see who has come to kill them! Look round: remember we are right to be proud!
Now, brave Hattori, we wait! There will be killing enough soon, but we will let our enemies make some mistakes before we begin!
Now, Hattori warriors, the time of battle has come. Today, we step out of the shadows and slaughter our foes openly. This is most worthy!
As long as we live, we fight, my Hattori brothers! That alone should make our enemies weak with fear! Who dare stands against us?
And now, brave Hattori, all is prepared for battle! Better yet, even our cunning is a weapon! Our foes already fear what they cannot see!
Warriors of the Hojo! We face a fierce enemy: indulge in no glory-hunting today! Do not waste time collecting heads from your foes.
Noble Hojo! Stand proudly, and show the enemy that we have come to show them what being a warrior means. They will not like this lesson!
I will not speak for long, men of the Hojo. I know that duty burns in all of you: the fire that forges courage in your hearts!
Stand, men of the Hojo! Look at your enemies, and see men as far beneath you as scuttling rats in a leaky rice store!
Now we are ready! Our strength is that of a fortress! Every man knows his duty, and will do it, for we are the Hojo!
We Hojo should remember, as we fight, that we are mighty, like a fortress: solid, impregnable, and unshakable! As long as we live, we fight!
Let the enemy hurl themselves against us like a storm blows across the heavens! They are nothing! We Hojo will be as stone, immune to their pathetic attacks!
We will hold against whatever the enemy can throw against us! We will be a fortress, stronger than stone, for we are Hojo warriors!
Sons of the Hojo, stand ready! Our ancestors watch over us. The duty to their memory is a heavy burden, but we must bear it manfully!
We Hojo are great builders! We are masters of stone and fortresses. There is nothing we cannot achieve. Here, now, we will achieve victory!
Men of the Mori! All stands ready! Our banners drift on the wind, and we will be like them: proud, strong, defiant! And we will be victorious!
Now, sons of the Mori clan, stand ready! Soon our foes will learn of their stupidity in opposing us, the masters of the waves!
My children! My warriors! We Mori are now ready for this battle! It will be a hard fight, but we are used to fighting wind, waves and men!
Mori warriors! The time of battle is come! We must be like the onrushing tide: endless, dangerous, unstoppable, overwhelming and unforgiving!
Now, my Mori warriors, prepare! This is our time! The moment has come to show Japan that we are men to be feared and respected!
Now comes the time when we must prove the Mori are worthy! Let none who hear of our actions today ever doubt our courage!
After battle is done, we loot! Our enemies call the Mori pirates and brigands, so let us be that and worse! We will have glory, and riches!
Sons of the Mori! We stand ready to do battle, and to gain fame, wealth and honour! All of these, and more, will be yours!
I am proud, solders of the Mori clan, to be your leader! You are without equals as fighters, and certainly without equals in this battle!
Stand ready! We have come for our Mori honour, insulted as it is by those who call us pirates! Now, we prove that we are warriors!
And now, warriors, prepare! We Oda are soldiers first and always, and a true soldier always treats his sword better than his woman! Ha!
Make ready, Oda warriors, make ready! I will not keep you long from the killing. That is the extent of our duty here: killing the enemy.
Now, Oda warriors, remember that we obey! We have discipline in our hearts, and devotion to our clan! These are the bedrock of our strength!
Prepare, men of the Oda clan! We are here to do bloody and dangerous work! We will not defeat our enemies: we will exterminate them!
After this fight our deeds here should be a tale to freeze a man's blood! We Oda must become a byword for death!
It is time to show our foes what Oda warriors can do! I expect discipline and obedience, and I expect you to kill and kill again!
Warriors of the Oda! Today we fight! But leave one man alive, so that he can spread fear of the Oda among our enemies!
Warriors of the Oda clan! Our strength lies in our discipline and devotion to our clan! Stand with your brothers, and all will be well!
Mighty soldiers of Oda clan! Let your watchwords be "Obedience! Obedience! Obedience!" Without duty, we are nothing, and are lost! With it, we are unconquered!
Now, men of the Oda clan, we are ready! Your opponents mock you for your dedication and loyalty! I will not mock them, for that is unworthy!
Loyal sons of the Shimazu! I salute you on this auspicious day! What manner of fools would dare stand against you?
Shimazu! Remember your ancestors as you go into battle! They were mighty men, and sired mighty sons! Be worthy of them!
You are worthy sons of the Shimazu! Your fame will live ten thousand years! That is right and proper! You will prove it shortly!
I draw my sword, Shimazu warriors! I do not expect to sheathe it again until we have victory or death. I know my duty! Do yours today!
Lift up our banners, noble sons of the Shimazu! Let the enemy see who has come against them! Let them doubt their wisdom and courage!
Now, my brothers, we will prove that Shimazu glory and courage are undimmed! Our ancestors will watch, and celebrate our deeds!
Our forebears were mighty men, and rightly we celebrate their greatness. Look up at our Shimazu banners, and remember they represent that awesome tradition!
Noble Shimazu, be proud as you await battle! The blood of heroes runs in our veins! Our blood will hallow this place with greatness!
To be a Shimazu warrior is to be an heir to greatness. It is to be sword in the hand of the Shimazu daimyo! It is to be honour made flesh!
Shimazu! Shimazu! Shimazu! What else need I cry to convince you we are strong and ready for battle? Make our ancestors proud!
We Takeda are famed throughout Japan for our horsemanship. This is entirely right! But we should also be respected for our fierce spirit, bred in the mountains!
Men of the Takeda clan: it is time to show your worth! Be strong as a mountain wind; fast as a mountain stream; terrible as an avalanche!
Now, soldiers of the Takeda, take heart! Your enemies have seen our banners, and fear begins its work. They do not speak of it, but it is there!
Sons of the Takeda! We have much to uphold here today! And I have no doubts that we will acquit ourselves with honour and courage!
Now, Takeda warriors, look to your duties! This is the moment of destiny, when fate guides our swords and we send our enemies to Hell!
There are no prouder boast than these: I am a Takeda general! I lead the greatest warriors in Japan! I never need doubt victory!
Unfurl our Takeda banners! We are ready now, and our enemies should be told! Let them see our strength, so that fear gnaws at their guts!
Noble Takeda, stand ready! We are men of the mountains, as hard as the rocks that bred us! Our enemies will now discover this!
Stand ready, you Takeda warriors! Our opponents call us "mountain monkeys" and "horse lovers". In return, I say nothing. We Takeda are better than that!
And now, we are come to battle, my Takeda brothers. What could be finer? If we fall, we die in the service of our noble clan!
We Tokugawa are thought to be diplomats rather than soldiers. We are both, for the sword can deceive and the tongue can be cutting! Today, we cut!
When we are done here, the name "Tokugawa" should strike fear into our foes' hearts. They should quail when they hear any Tokugawa speak of this day!
I will speak plainly: we face a battle. But this is nothing for we are Tokugawa warriors, and the sword is always to hand!
The sight of our Tokugawa banners is enough to un-man lesser soldiers. Even now, your enemies are wondering where they might find a latrine!
When tales are told about this battle, when poets write of our exploits, let the name of Tokugawa shine brightly! We will inspire awe and fear!
Remember this day, and tell the story to your children and grandchildren as yet unborn! Let them know what it is to be a Tokugawa warrior!
Today we fight! Let us show the world that the Tokugawa clan are skilled in war as well as peace, and that our souls have iron in them!
Now, warriors of the Tokugawa, put aside your cares, your thoughts of life. Embrace death, and duty, and all will be well as we fight today!
Now, Tokugawa warriors, unleash your righteous fury! Our enemies think us men of words alone! Let us show them that we are men of the sword!
Now we fight! Later we will tell tales of our deeds today, of how the Tokugawa once again proved their skill in warfare!
So, my Uesugi brothers, we stand ready for a fight. Our faith will sustain us in what is to come. Our strength will give us victory!
Draw strength from your faith, my brother warriors! We Uesugi are a pious people, and that makes us better fighters! May our victory prayers be answered!
Lift our banners to the heavens! Let everyone see that the Uesugi are come to battle, and that we are resolute and set on our path!
Now, my brother warriors, my brave fellows, we are ready! The Uesugi never shirk their duty, or break with their faith! Now, let us fight!
Now, my loyal warriors, finish your prayers. It is time for battle. Let our battle cry be: "Uesugi! Uesugi! Uesugi!" It is a proud name!
And now, Uesugi warriors, say your last prayers. Do not think of your loved ones, only of your unshakable duty and faith. On that path lies victory!
